The speech read as follows-

Mr President, the Administrative Services Legislation Amendment Bill contains amendments to a number of Acts administered by the Administrative Services portfolio. The amendments are of a kind which, in recent years, it has been the practice to include in an omnibus Bill.
Amendment of the Public Works Committee Act 1969

As Honourable Senators will be aware, the Public Works Committee Act 1969 established the Public Works Committee to scrutinise the Executive's expenditure on public works. Since the inception of the Committee, departments and to an extent the Committee itself, have regarded works as being limited to those of a permanent architectural or engineering nature carried out for or by the Government. Movable works, such as the construction of a ship, have long been regarded as being of the nature of specialised procurement which ought not to be subject to the Act.

However, in recent years, legal advice to the effect that movable works may in certain circumstances indeed be works within the terms of the Public Works Committee Act, has called this view into question. To remove the ambiguity as to what comes within the definition of a work for the purpose of the Act, the amendments introduced by this Bill provide that a work means an architectural or engineering work and specifically excludes intangible things, movable works and engineering equipment not being integral components of a work.

The Bill also expands the definition of work to ensure that works which are financed by deferred payment or similar arrangements are referrable to the Committee. In these times of economic restraint Government bodies are increasingly turning to alternative methods of financing their public works. Under a deferred payment arrangement, the Government body is not required to finance the work during construction, but effectively, it is paid off by instalments after occupancy. Such alternatives to traditional funding are attractive, but in some situations the relevant works are not referrable to the Committee under the existing provisions of the Act. Where there is a clear intention for the Government and its agencies to become the owner of such facilities, the amendment will allow the Public Works Committee to fulfil its established role.

The Bill also provides that after consultation with the Committee, types of works can be declared to be works or public works by regulation for the purposes of the Act. Similarly, types or works can also be declared not to be works or public works by regulation. This approach is intended to facilitate consideration of new types of projects and delivery systems and to meet changing circumstances.
Amendment of the Protective Service Act 1987

The amendments of the Australian Protective Service Act 1987 extend the powers of arrest of protective service officers to the offences of escaping from lawful custody, aiding a person to escape from lawful custody or rescuing a person by force from lawful custody which were recently created by amendments to the Crimes Act 1914. This is essentially a consequential amendment.
Amendment of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973

Honourable senators may be aware that presently the Chairman of the Grants Commission must be appointed on a full-time basis, whereas members can be appointed on either a full-time or part-time basis. The amendments to the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973 provide for the option of appointing the Chairman also on a full-time or a part-time basis.
Amendment of the Parliament House Construction Authority Act 1979

The Parliament House Construction Authority will have successfully completed the major phase of the design and construction of the new Parliament House by early 1989. There are however financial and legal tasks related to the completion and termination of over 500 contracts requiring further work over the next two to three years. There are also minor construction works remaining to be completed.

While the functions to be undertaken by the Authority after early 1989 continue to be very important to the completion of the project, the range of matters to be managed will be more restricted than in earlier years. Consequently, the Government considers that the range of skills and experience required by Authority board members in this period would not need to be as diverse as those required for the current and previous boards.
In recognition of the change in nature and scope of the remaining work the Government took two decisions:
(i) that the Authority was to complete its remaining work and be terminated in June 1991, and

(ii) consonant with the wind down phase commencing early in 1989, from that time the Authority board would be restructured reducing its numbers from 6 to 3 part-time members including the position of chairman.
This Bill puts into effect the later decision. It is the Government's intention to bring forward in 1991 appropriate legislation terminating the Authority.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the adjournment of the debate last evening, I was speaking to the three points on which the Australian Democrats believe there needs to be more emphasis from Australian representatives at the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. They are: endeavours to alleviate poverty, particularly in Third World countries; the need to look at environmental degradation; and the requirement to take into account the legitimate desires of indigenous peoples.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the first item, the alleviation of poverty, American economists Bruce Russett and David Sylvan have considered the social opportunity costs of certain expenditure, particularly military expenditure, in Third World countries. They found that for an average developing country with a population of 8.5 million and a gross national product of around $US350m, the first $200m of arms imports would lead to approximately 20 additional infant deaths per 1,000 live births; decreased average life expectancy of three to four years; and 13 to 14 fewer literate adults out of every hundred in the adult population. These are extraordinary statistics. There is the direct linkage between arms imports by those poor countries and the lessening of the amount spent on health, education and general social conditions.

Indeed, one wonders whether the multilateral finance institutions should start making arms reductions a condition of loans to developing countries. After all, the International Monetary Fund is known for the socially harsh conditions which it places on its balance of payments loans to countries. Countries are required to cut public expenditure, particularly in the area of social expenditure, and raise interest rates to stabilise their external balance of payments. Military expenditure, however, seems to be a matter of total indifference to the International Monetary Fund when it imposes those types of conditions.

Investing in poverty alleviation just happens to make good economic sense. It is not charity. Study after study has shown that investments in poverty alleviation and human capital formation are not less economically productive than investments in infrastructure, energy or industry. On the contrary, empirical research shows that satisfying human needs yields high rates of economic return. This is, in fact, borne out by World Bank figures comparing the economic gains from poverty-oriented projects and non-poverty oriented projects in rural areas. As a footnote, I point out that the World Bank considers the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) a good means of directly overcoming poverty at the grass roots level. The bank, in last year's document, one that I have already mentioned-that is, the World Bank's support for the alleviation of poverty-says that it is cooperating with IFAD in 122 projects. The two organisations are cofinancing 78 projects and IFAD is coordinating its interventions in countries undertaking bank supported structural adjustment programs such as Ghana and Guinea-Bissau. The bank states:

Experience with these and other initiatives can greatly enhance the Bank's understanding of which programs work and why, as well as provide valuable support for efforts to protect the poor during periods of adjustment.

However, we noted that the Australian Government does not seem to appear to concur with the bank's view of IFAD since it announced some time ago that it does not plan to replenish its contributions to the fund. The Australian Democrats urge the new Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to review this particular decision since it seems an extremely shortsighted one in terms of the major thrust which the World Bank has identified as necessary and which has been supported by members of all parties in this place.

The second item to which I wish to refer is environmental degradation. Poverty alleviation and overcoming Third World debt are, I believe, closely intertwined with preventing environmental degradation in those Third World countries. Countries facing crippling debt interest payments are more likely to destroy wilderness and rainforest and misuse rural land in their efforts to increase commodity exports and gain export dollars to pay those debts. We have seen this in country after country. Unless poverty is overcome, the rural poor farm flood-prone valleys and rapidly eroding hillsides. Poor people cannot afford to invest in conservation measures or grow crops which take a long time to mature. Urban poor live in crowded and unsanitary conditions and are hurt most by flooding, water pollution and congestion. On a grander scale, industrialisation in the Third World must take account of the greenhouse effect on the entire planet of further emissions into the atmosphere. Yet the developing world is hardly likely to accept regulations on its development, certainly those imposed from without, while the developed world continues to pursue self-interested economic and environmental policies.

As the World Bank itself has noted, wealthier countries directly damage the global environment by transmitting pollutants and by using developing countries as `pollutant havens' for industry at the same time that they voice increasing concern about the preservation of species and ecosystems, pointing to the direct hypocrisy of countries such as ours. Industrial countries continue to pursue pricing policies and trade restrictions which are massively destructive of the economies in those countries, either by preventing them from exporting agricultural products or by encouraging them to deplete their natural resource base without adequate compensation. In April 1987 the United Nations World Commission on Environment and Development concluded in its report entitled Our Common Future that environmental management should be integrated into economic planning; that public participation is required; and that economic growth, the alleviation of poverty and sound environmental management are in many cases mutually consistent objectives. Clearly then, through the World Bank, developed countries can, at least in part, meet their economic and humanitarian responsibilities to the developing world. Through the World Bank, at least in part, Third World development can be environmentally sustainable.

The third item that I raise-that is, the needs of indigenous people-is one which unfortunately has not received a great deal of attention. The development policies of the IBRD and other arms of the World Bank must become increasingly sensitive to the Fourth World, the world of the planet's remaining indigenous peoples. Fourth World people are those still living tribal or semi-tribal lives. In many cases they do not identify with the sovereign states within whose borders they live. In many cases also they live and travel backwards and forwards across international borders. Development policies must allow their cultures to evolve; they must not destroy those cultures and leave the people alienated and therefore more likely to become part of the rural and urban poor.

More effort needs to be put into understanding that culture is a form of knowledge. We have in the past-and even at present we are doing it-pushed extremely poor educational development policies, for example, those which can destroy the knowledge base within a particular community. If I may give a concrete example of this, a study in a Mexican village showed that non-Indian school-age children were able to identify the uses of 37 plants. In contrast, Otomi Indian children in that village could identify the uses of 138 plants. That is an enormous difference. In spite of this, a development program which was being funded saw the Indian children as `ignorant' and in need of education. In other words, there was a total mismatch in that the people who were coming in lacked a sympathetic understanding of the knowledge base of those indigenous people. Of course, the danger there is that those educational activities could in fact destroy the indigenous knowledge base rather than supplement it. In destroying that base, they could very well destroy the livelihood of many of those people.

This is an area that, hopefully, will become of greater interest to members of this chamber because it is one with which Australia is intimately involved and it is one to which, through our activities in the World Bank, we need to make sure that other countries pay attention.

I have outlined why the Democrats believe that poverty alleviation, environmental protection and the rights of indigenous people are important. What we are looking for is that Australia's representatives at the World Bank promote these concerns and monitor the effectiveness of the bank's response to them. We are looking for more extensive annual reporting to parliament of Australia's participation in World Bank fora. That reporting should include an assessment of the effectiveness of the bank's efforts in the areas of which I have spoken.

I foreshadow that in the committee stage I shall ask a number of questions concerned with the availability and extent of the material that we receive, particularly that material which is provided to Australia and which is declassified by the World Bank-in other words, it is freely available-and yet which has never been included in annual reports to this Parliament. If Senator Messner's amendment is not carried I foreshadow that, at the second reading stage of the debate, I will move an amendment which has been circulated in my name. I point out also that, in the committee stage, I wish to move a substantive amendment directed at that reporting mechanism so that this Parliament can be better informed and so that those parliamentarians from all political parties who have signed letters to the World Bank over the last couple of years in regard to the three items that I have been speaking about will be better informed as to the movements within the World Bank. With that information these debates about whether we should continue our activity or whether we should move our resources to some other area would be better informed.

At the moment I am concerned that the debates we have in this place are based on information that we receive from outside the country rather than from inside the country. We know that the material is being received by the Australian Government. The difficulty is that, while it is not classified by the World Bank, it seems to be classified by the departments that receive it in Australia. I think that is a pity because these are matters that concern the Australian community. The Australian community is putting up the dollars for this activity and I think it has a right to be informed of the developmental philosophies of the World Bank-not just who we have sitting on the board and how much money is being moved around.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (General Capital Increase) Bill 1988 will provide parliamentary approval for Australia to take up part of its allocated subscription to increase the capital of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), sometimes referred to as the World Bank. Although it has 151 member countries it is not quite a world bank, as countries such as Russia and some other notable countries are not members. Australia is entitled to subscribe to 10,734 shares before September 1992 and the Federal Government has decided to subscribe approximately 73 per cent of its entitlement, which it has been estimated will cost Australia about $US28 1/2m. In fact, Australia is about the thirteenth major source of funds for the bank, accounting for about 2 per cent of total funds.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to remind the Senate that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) said in his second reading speech:
Australia is a strong, but not uncritical, supporter of the IBRD.

The Opposition endorses those words but it feels that the country can do more to monitor the programs and priorities of the bank in pursuing its goals. This is especially so when we consider the growing indebtedness of many of the bank's major clients and the realistic conclusion that many will not for a long period, if ever, have a capacity to repay their loans. I refer specifically to Latin American countries and also to countries in sub-Saharan Africa.

I believe that the President of the bank, Mr Barber Conable, is very sincere in his wish for the bank to assume a more invigorated role, as he has outlined in his report of September 1987. The President was encouraging the World Bank to be more circumspect in its lending activities and, at the same time, much more appreciative of the pressures on many underdeveloped countries. On the one hand, many countries are endeavouring to lay a firm fiscal infrastructure in their own national economies and, on the other hand, some of them are trying to compete generally on the global market in the raw material area-a very difficult exercise.

The President, since coming to that high office, has reduced the bureaucracy of the World Bank by several hundred positions but unfortunately, in some people's view, it still has too many people because it is still over 6,000 strong. I hope that a leaner structure in future will also bring with it a higher degree of responsiveness. The bank dispenses cash to the poor amongst its members, either to governments or to private sector groups undertaking projects guaranteed by their governments.

Not only has the World Bank increased the provision for loan losses to cover bad debts from $100m to $500m but it has also encouraged nations to increase and elongate debt. Eight borrowers from the World Bank are presently in arrears. The most indebted nation is Peru, which owes $US1.2 billion. Others on this formidable list include Panama, Nicaragua, Guyana, Liberia, Sierra Leone, Zambia and Syria. With the exception of Syria, all these countries are in Central Africa or Central and South America. The legislation in effect will recommit Australia to picking up part of the cost for programs and loans that the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development dispenses. To that extent, it should not be a step that is taken lightly. Indeed, the American Congress had a very extensive and drawn out debate before it decided to increase the capital because of the disquiet that many congressmen felt about the role of the World Bank, particularly some of its past policies which they believed tended to promote socialism, thwarted United States foreign policy and supported corrupt governments. I hope, therefore, that honourable senators in this place will also reflect not only on the specifics of this Bill but also on what it partially represents-that is, an enduring commitment to take part in the financial charter of the World Bank.

Australia has been a member of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development since 1947 following its establishment. As its name implies, it was established to aid postwar reconstruction and development, particularly in newly independent countries or those in Europe whose industrial bases were destroyed by war. After the resurrection of European industry, the bank turned its focus to the Third World. Regrettably, many Third World countries which the bank has assisted since the 1950s have been run by undemocratic governments and, in some cases, dictatorships. Thus, the World Bank has achieved in some circles an unfortunate profile of supporting the political stances of some of these governments through support for programs in their countries. Some critics say that the bank has a preoccupation with infrastructures rather than with poverty, with having preferences for dams and petrochemical plants and with displacing indigenous people from their land by virtue of some of its programs. In fact, President Aquino inherited debts over the corruption financed nuclear power plant in the Philippines.

Because of this political colouring of the World Bank's work and the nature of many of the economies that it assists, much of the money spent by the World Bank effectively can be said to become aid. The World Bank is not an aid agency and should not have been developed in this manner. Indeed, the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau has estimated that the World Bank is three times less efficient in the disbursement of funds than AIDAB itself. But unlike AIDAB, the World Bank has no national government to whom it is responsible for efficiency and the allocation of funds. Thus, in this regard, the World Bank has degenerated, in my view and in the view of many on this side of the Parliament, to an inefficient aid agency, losing sight of the objectives of its boundaries and losing control over the specific end purpose of many of its program funds.

To this degree, I am disturbed about some of the activities of the World Bank and its role in the economy. However, the Opposition supports the original aims of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and hopes that it will move in a number of directions: first, stop increasing loans to countries whose capacity to pay diminishes proportionately and, secondly, stop seeing itself as a quasi aid agency. National governments have their own aid agencies and are at least able to be accountable to their respective parliaments.

Finally, I think that there is need for the Western world to face up to two issues: firstly, too harsh an application of economic stringency and enforced reduction of living standards will bring an adverse and hostile reaction from debtor countries with consequent loss of goodwill. I draw the Senate's attention to recent events in Venezuela. There has been a degree of revolution there because of the commitment of that country's Government to force down the standard of living of workers to help repay international debts. The second issue is that a hard core of the debt needs to be absorbed, shared and written off by the lender agency to enable a reasonable ratio of debt repayment to export income, because some countries now find themselves in a quite impossible position in servicing debt.

On the other hand, there is a responsibility on the part of debtor countries not to squander money. Countries which have very poor base economies are having their economies further eroded by the development of huge, unnecessary, grandiose schemes, such as the replica of the Basilica of Rome which is being constructed along the Ivory Coast.

While the bank is facing unprecedented criticism, the bulk of its lending is to stable governments. Despite politically motivated difficulties, it has still provided a number of worthwhile projects, including some extensive reafforestation items. I hope that some of my concerns expressed today will be heeded by the World Bank bureaucrats and the Australian Treasury, which gives advice on how many shares will be subscribed to.

While I criticise the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, I believe that there are some parallels in Australia. The Government has been as negligent as the bank in some areas, that is, in its attention to the management of the Australian economy and its failure to implement appropriate measures to curb the development of stagflation. So we have a parallel situation. Our balance of payments problems not only are a reaction to an overheated domestic demand but also reflect Australia's problems because of our dependence on a few export commodities of the unprocessed kind-problems which are faced by many of the debtor nations to which the World Bank provides funds. At home our problems reveal our import dependence on capital equipment and industrial supplies.

The ineffectiveness of government monetary policy to stave off inflation and its implications on the well-being of the economy is a matter of which everybody should take note. In fact, we get continual reminders from informed sources. The National Australia Bank Economist of 13 February said that the tight monetary policy with subsequent high professional market interest rates appears set to continue. It is worrying when the market advisers keep giving us information which is contrary to that given by the Government's best advisers, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It is confusing and must be worrying to business when the political masters do not seem to know, or do not want to know, what is happening in our economy.

We are told that interest rates may need to go quite a lot higher before they bite economic activity. The firming of United States interest rates will also lead to our own interest rates being sustained at high levels. What is happening in Germany and across Europe supports this contention. What the Government does not realise is that there is a time lag between changes in interest rates and their effectiveness in the economy. The evidence of the past two credit squeezes in 1974 and 1981 shows that monetary policy takes a long time to bite, but it has real teeth when it does.

This aspect does not seem to have been appreciated by either the Prime Minister or by the Treasurer. High interest rates increase the speculative effect from overseas. However, the gains made to Australia do not offset the balance of payments problems because essentially it is hot money that is drawn in. There is no short term relief for inflation or for the current account deficit. Contrary to what the Treasurer says, there is no short term relief on the interest rates front. The intended rise in interest rates to take the heat out of the labour market and slow wages, inflation and imports has not been fully realised. Prices, imports and the demand for a rise in wages and tax cuts have continued to increase, which implies that a recession is looming. All these will impact on the cost of living.

Australia is deficient in domestic savings. My colleague Senator Parer gave a marvellous notice of motion this morning pointing out the gravity of the situation. It is also reflected in the current account deficit and the consequent rise in external debt. The domestic demand for savings funds has exceeded the supply of domestic funds, with the shortfall being covered by borrowings from overseas. To reverse this trend, savings will have to increase to between 3 and 4 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) from the present level.

The four main indicators of saving reflect the fact that consumer debt has risen over the past decade. Australia has unsatisfactory ratios of debt to household income, interest to disposable income, debt to household assets, and real debt per capita. No wonder our standard of living is falling. From the 1970s to the 1980s consumer debt rose on all four indicators. However, there has been a small decline in all four indicators following the collapse of the sharemarket in October 1987. But the fact that that crash occurred is no credit to the Government. Australia's lack of savings, therefore, impinges on its international trade performance and, in part, on our trade imbalance because we need to borrow from overseas to satisfy our demand. We are now borrowing from overseas in an environment of increasing interest rates in North America and Europe.

The investment position is equally bleak. Investment outlays were lower in 1988 than in 1981-82. Business investment as a share of GDP in the September quarter of 1988 was 11.4 per cent lower than the ratio for the previous three quarters and lower than the ratio which applied in the last quarter of 1981 and the first two quarters of 1982. Australia depends on the importation of capital goods and industry supplies, as we have no significant import substitution industries for these goods. The consequence is that the import of investment goods always has an impact on the current account deficit which, therefore, weakens our balance of payments.

Regrettably, we have been misled. There is not a lot of evidence to support the view that higher investment will pump out sufficient exports, including import competing exports, to restore the current account deficit. Funds are going into consumer goods and not into capital goods which would enhance our export performance. Our exports need to grow 5 per cent faster than our imports for at least two years just to get our external debt level stable, with a constant Australian dollar and high commodity prices. That is how serious it is. The trend in our current account deficit has continued to deteriorate since 1970, as most of our spending on imports is on consumer goods rather than on capital goods designed for export enhancement.

Capital imports as a share of total imports fell from the six months ended December 1987 to the six months ended December 1988. This implies that imports of consumer and other goods are responsible to a large degree for the strong import growth which has boosted our current account deficit. High interest rates have not dampened domestic demand or discouraged imports. I remind the Senate of their time lag, which means that when they bite they are going to bite very savagely, and it is therefore going to be difficult to turn off the tap quickly. In fact, imports have increased. There has been pressure on interest rates to rise due to increased demand for consumer goods and the relative ease in obtaining goods on credit. Due to deregulation of the financial market, credit is easy to obtain, apart from the cost of servicing it, and the effects on the balance of payments are significant.

Under this Government tax increases, which account for 25.5 per cent of all gross domestic product, have increased revenue by $41 billion. Under the Hawke Government, personal taxes have increased by 100 per cent and sales tax by 107 per cent. The Budget surplus could be somewhat closer to $6 billion than the $5 billion estimated last August. Treasury officers estimate a Budget surplus of almost $7 billion this year and $12 billion next year if conservative forecasts are assumed. The blow-out in the current account deficit, the increase in the inflation rate and a strong reliance on monetary policy have weakened Australia's economic position. The Government needs to look at its role in the fiscal and wages policy area to effect a more positive economic climate in Australia, because the effect of our spending has been to blow out our balance of payments deficit. Our balance of payments deficit for January was the worst January figure on record, about three times the deficit recorded for January last year. The Government's Budget forecast for 1988-89 of $9.5 billion has already been exceeded. Indeed, the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), explained in the House that a Morgan Guaranty Australia Ltd trust company study had shown that in 1986 our gross foreign debt was $101 billion, or 42 per cent of gross domestic product. Brazil's foreign debt at that time was 41 per cent of gross domestic product, almost a parallel situation. In fact Australia was not far behind the ailing Colombian economy.

The National Australia Bank forecast a current account deficit of about $14 billion for 1988-89, almost $2 billion more than the previous year and $4.5 billion up on the Budget forecast. That is indeed a problem for Australia. But what happens? We are told that the Government is sitting it out and not doing anything. In other words, it is burying its head in the sand in relation to Australia's economic problems. So the problems of declining savings rates, falling or flat productivity of the labour force, excessive reliance on government, a lack of competition in the market, a lack of incentive in the economic system, and the structure of the tax system have all got to be addressed. All these factors compound our balance of payments problem and reflect the lack of commitment to continuing sound economic management. It is, therefore, relevant that we compare Australia's performance with that of some of those ailing countries which the World Bank lends to, because after all many of those countries have been referred to by Mr Keating as banana republics. Australia could well go down that road unless the Government starts to take positive action and draws a May economic statement or a mini-Budget to address the major factors that are affecting the lives of millions of Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (General Capital Increase) Bill 1988. This Bill gives parliamentary approval for the contribution that Australia, along with other countries, makes towards reconstruction and development, particularly in Third World countries. I would like to direct my remarks to the amendment moved by Senator Messner to the motion for the second reading, in particular to paragraph (c), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: bearing in mind the fact that through the Bank Australia presumes to assist other economies:
(i) expresses alarm at the Hawke Government's lack of concern or urgency in addressing Australia's emerging economic crisis, which is evident to all but the out of touch Mr Keating and Mr Hawke;
(ii) further expresses concern at the collapse in family living standards since 1983, caused by a drop in purchasing power of at least $58 per week for families on average earnings;
(iii) urges the Hawke Labor Government to adopt policies to restore incentive to individuals to work and save, and to create job opportunities for their fellow Australians; and

(iv) condemns the Hawke Labor Government for its abject failure to implement change in vital areas of the economy such as the labour market, shipping and the waterfront, affecting Australia's ability to pay off its debts, raise living standards and compete on world markets.

At the end of August 1988, a little less than six months ago, this Government brought down its Budget for 1988-89. It is a government which, I understand, sometime this week will move into its seventh year of government. The questions that every Australian and the media are now asking are: what has been achieved, and how does the standard of living of the average Australian now compare to the standard of living of the average Australian in 1983? The answer, with very few exceptions, is that the great majority of Australians are far worse off. The honeymoon is over for this Government. The rhetoric has not been matched with results and promises of better days have not materialised. The light at the end of the tunnel has dimmed. It has got further and further away, notwithstanding the promises we have had year after year in subsequent Budgets. It is worth noting some of the quotes from the recent Budget Speech by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I will quote him, in part:
Just a short time ago we faced grave economic difficulties.
We have grave economic difficulties. They are worse than they have ever been previously. But that remark was the light offered by the Treasurer in the Budget Speech. The Treasurer went on:
Adverse world developments hacked into our export earnings; our national income shrank and foreign debt surged.

There had been a reduction in the terms of trade, I agree, but last year there was a massive increase in the terms of trade. I would like to ask: what has changed? The Treasurer said our foreign debt surged. Our foreign debt continues to surge. The implication in the Budget Speech was that somehow something had changed. The Treasurer went on:
. . . we are now well on the way back to prosperity.

What a joke! Do the members of this Government not talk to the average Australian? They would find out whether we were well on the way back to prosperity. All one has to do is to ask those on average weekly earnings, `What are your problems?' and they will give about three. The first is that interest rates have gone out of sight. They say, `We cannot afford our mortgage repayments'. Sure, the banks have been able to alleviate this to some extent by extending the time of payment. However, of course, the total payment for the purchase of a house has gone up substantially. I will come back to that later. The second answer average Australians will give is, `The prices our wives have to pay in the supermarkets for ordinary goods, whether they be--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Even in a second reading stage speech, this is really getting away from the Bill. It is more like a Appropriation Bill speech.
—I would ask the honourable senator to confine his remarks to the Bill before the House.
—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I was addressing my remarks to the amendment moved by Senator Messner.
—The amendment is a bit dubious, too, but I ask you to stay within those guidelines.
—On the point of order: the debate has been proceeding for about 2 1/2 hours and we have had no complaints about it so far.

—I remind the Senate that we are talking about the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (General Capital Increase) Bill and the amendment moved by Senator Messner to the motion for the second reading of that Bill. I indicated at the beginning of my speech that I would address my remarks to that area. Senator Messner has introduced his amendment because, while nobody disagrees that we have some sort of duty to perform in making payments to this bank, we also need to look in our own backyard. It was with that in mind that I was addressing those items.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is appropriate that we talk about the economic crisis in our own country while at the same time we seek to address the problems that occur in Third World countries. Some people would argue that this country, compared with many of its near neighbours, may well be approaching that Third World status. I could not help noting that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave gratuitous advice to Vietnam during a recent trip to South East Asia when he said, `If you're not careful and don't do something about it, you might end up as an island in a sea of progress in South East Asia'. Again, he ignored his own backyard. From the point of view of the manufacturing industry, for instance, we run that very grave risk. Some people would say that we are already facing that situation. Some of the figures that I will refer to shortly might well bear that out.

As part of a parliamentary team last year, I visited some Asian countries, including the Philippines and Korea. One could not help making the comparison between the Korea of 10 years ago and the Korea of today. Korea, 10 years ago, was a Third World country. It is still regarded as such by some. However, in that 10-year period that country has put us in a position, comparatively, from a manufacturing point of view, of approaching Third World status. I return to the remarks made by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech:
This year our balance of payments deficit will be halved from its peak of just three years ago.

He is nowhere near the mark. Our balance of payments deficit figures for the first seven months of this financial year were in excess of the Budget forecast. Senator Watson referred to the estimate made by various people that by the end of this year the figure may well be in excess of $14 billion. The Treasurer also said:
Our foreign debt burden has stabilised and begun to fall.

Our foreign debt burden has never been higher. I read in the paper today that the net foreign debt is in excess of $95 billion and presumably, with the reduction in the value of the dollar, we can expect it to be somewhat higher when the next figures are released. That sort of net foreign debt-the gross is in excess of $120 billion-is putting us in the same category as Latin American countries. It is, and should be, a cause of great concern. This is the reason for Senator Messner's amendment, in which he points out that we are alarmed at this Government's lack of concern or urgency in addressing the economic crisis which is evident to everybody except, apparently, the Prime Minister of this country, the Treasurer and the Government. The Treasurer pointed out in his speech:
On the export front, new manufacturing activities and tourism have blossomed.

Certainly, tourism has blossomed but not because of this Government, although I agree that the television advertisements arranged by Paul Hogan some years ago in the United States were a success. However, the major reason for the success-there are always two sides to the coin-has been the growing investment, mainly by the Japanese, in our tourist developments. This is attracting more and more people, mainly to my own State of Queensland.

The only comment in the 1988-89 Budget Speech that made any sense-but again the rhetoric was not backed up by any sort of performance-was that we must abandon forever the myopic view that the world owes us a living and will go on bankrolling us whatever we do. Let us examine these brave, optimistic words. I do not mind the Government talking up the economy if it can, but talking on its own is not enough; there must be action and this Government is not taking any action. As I mentioned earlier, the Government forecast a reduction in the current account deficit, a reduction in debt and so on. In seven months we have achieved a $9.6 billion deficit. The Budget forecast was $9.5 billion. The Government subsequently amended it upwards after only a couple of months-not a long time.

The level of inflation is of great concern. That is something that governments can have some control over. In his amendment in relation to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development Bill, Senator Messner stated his concern about the collapse in family living standards since 1983 caused by a drop in purchasing power of at least $58 a week for families on average weekly earnings. Only yesterday the Australian Institute of Family Studies put out its report with its recommendations. It is obvious to everyone that the standard of living of average Australians has diminished dramatically. In fact, a one income family on average weekly earnings with two children has lost $41 in real disposable income over the past four years under the Hawke Government. There have been some gainers, and the gainers have been those people whose average weekly income is less than one-half of average weekly earnings and those at the top end of the scale. Again, it shows how gratuitous advice given to other people about the way in which they should run their economies has thus diverted attention from the quite disastrous results being imposed upon Australian people.

The other matter is interest rates. Interest rates are a wonderful saga. This Government has an appalling record on what it has said and done about interest rates in Australia. It is worth quoting a few comments made by our own Prime Minister. Was he acting out of ignorance, or was he saying things because it suited him politically before an election or a by-election? During the election campaign in 1987 the Prime Minister said:
Interest rates are again falling and under Labor will continue to fall . . . Labor will continue to pursue policies which will allow interest rates to fall further.
At a press conference in July 1987 he said:
Interest rates as you know are falling and will continue to fall and mortgage rates are . . . expected to fall before the end of 1987.

He said in January 1989 that home loan interest rates will go down this year. The facts on interest rates present quite a different story. Since June 1988 short term interest rates have increased from 13.5 per cent to 15.5 per cent, and the prime interest rate today has risen from about 15 per cent to about 17 1/2 to 18 per cent. Those are the problems that affect ordinary Australians.

In recent times the question of savings has been raised. Australia has one of the lowest savings ratios in the industrialised world. There is a good reason for that. There is a complete disincentive for people to save. People want to save, and they have two options. They can put their money into a home which protects their savings. It is what I referred to in a previous speech some time ago as the `gold mentality', which has been introduced into this economy by this Government. Honourable senators will be aware that when things get tough in the Third World countries-the very area that this Bill covers-people tend to invest in gold because it protects their savings and can be easily transferred into some other commodity. It may also be a method of escaping from a country that has economic and political difficulties. That is what has happened here. When speaking about-with which no-one agrees, including the Labor back bench-the road back to prosperity, the Treasurer, in his Budget Speech, said:
This is because the Government moved quickly to institute a unique set of policy arrangements which have created the right conditions for recovery.
What unique set of policy arrangements? The Government keeps talking about waiting until the structural improvements it has instituted take effect. What structural improvements?

TALK.START.PARA: —Restructuring for ACTU awards.

—I thank Senator Stone very much. He is quite right. The Treasurer talks about his levers. The only levers he uses are forward and reverse with monetary policy and interest rates. He works on the basis that if we squeeze the interest rates up to great heights this will dampen the economy and improve our balance of payments problems. That is the only unique set of policy arrangements that he has. I have not been able to detect any others. This brings me to the final point of Senator Messner's amendment, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . its abject failure to implement changes in vital areas of the economy such as the labour market, shipping and the waterfront, affecting Australia's ability to pay off its debts, raise living standards and compete on world markets.

If we are to get back on track in Australia, the key area that must be addressed is our ability to compete on world markets, in respect of both exports and import replacement. From a productivity point of view we have gone nowhere. There has been some slight improvement, but it does not rate when compared with the improvement of our closest neighbours. After all, this is a competitive world. We are in a competitive world today. We cannot avoid it. We cannot duck it. The Government is now going into its seventh year. At this stage it has still not addressed any of the micro-economic problems that confront this country. I see that Senator Cook is nodding. Of the new Ministers, he may be one that is moving in the right direction, but I notice from the newspapers in recent times that he is getting a rough time from his colleagues. I suggest that he keep moving in the direction he has taken in an effort to do the things that must be done if we are to get away from the quite disastrous economic situation in which Australia finds itself simply because of the inaction of the Prime Minister and the majority of his Government, who are more interested in political survival than in the survival of this great nation of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Messner's amendment to the motion for the second reading of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (General Capital Increase) Bill 1988. I refer in particular to the first two paragraphs of Senator Messner's amendment, the first of which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) notes that a thorough analysis of Australia's contribution to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is long overdue;
I would personally underline those words from some experience in the past with that organisation. The second paragraph of Senator Messner's amendment reads:

(b) further notes that, in future, the Australian Government should take a more active role in the forums of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, to explain this country's growing concerns with the Bank's management and direction, and to convey the message that a more efficient utilisation of the Bank's existing resources must eventuate before further contributions to its capital base will be provided;
I will speak on those two paragraphs of Senator Messner's amendment before addressing myself to the remainder of it.

I spent the four years from 1967 to 1970 sitting on the Executive Board of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development in Washington. I had the honour there to represent not only Australia but also the other two members of our constituency, as it was called at that time, namely, New Zealand and South Africa. They were fascinating years because we saw the beginning of what has subsequently been a transformation of that institution. That transformation, while containing many good aspects, has also contained a good many steps in directions which, if not wrong, have at been least questionable. That all began under Mr Robert McNamara, who came to the bank as its President in about March 1968. He began at about that time to work out some of the guilt which he was feeling, not necessarily correctly, about his personal involvement with the United States involvement in the war in Vietnam. That is not a matter about which I think he should have felt any guilt whatsoever, but perhaps there were personal aspects of that matter which weighed on his mind. Certainly the attacks upon him would have led to that. I do not want to criticise Mr McNamara personally; I am simply looking for an explanation for some of his actions while in the bank. Mr McNamara took the bank from being a very proper, fully sound financial institution going about the highly constructive and productive business of assisting developing countries in the world improve the state of their economies and increase their productiveness towards being an assistance agency. It was called a development assistance agency, but the emphasis tended to be more on assistance than development. If we are to find where the bank went wrong in the succeeding 20 years, we have to start back there. But that is history and we are now addressing 1989.

Over the last four or five years in particular the bank, as part of that general stream of change within it, has moved more towards a process of providing money to the developing countries which are its members on less strict conditions and with easier availability. The chief instrument the bank has used for that purpose has been its so-called structural adjustment loans, which basically provide funds to developing country borrowers to ease their balance of payments and debt repayment problems, supposedly conditional upon the setting in place by those countries, in undertakings given to the bank, of so-called structural adjustment programs. The country might undertake, for example, to reform its tariff system, to stop using its exchange rate in various contrived ways, or to get out of a number of enterprises in which its government may be unproductively involved, and the like. Countries may enter into such programs in order to obtain access to structural adjustment loans from the World Bank.

Some of those programs have been fully successful, but in too many cases we have found that, having taken the money and run with it, the countries involved have not kept up their end of the bargain and have not fulfilled their undertakings with respect to the structural assistance programs. The whole point about structural adjustment loans is that they are fast disbursing loans. The money is paid out quickly, the country receives it and then has a debt, but the bank no longer has much say over further conditions. It may very well be that if this country continues on the rake's progress on which the Hawke Government has embarked it in the past six years it will have to apply in five or 10 years time-if there were no change in that outlook-for structural adjustment programs from the World Bank to make up for the ones which this Government, having talked a great deal about structural adjustment, has not followed through. However, that is a digression. The truth is that there is also today an unfortunate degree of in-fighting between the otherwise highly professional staff of the World Bank and the equally highly professional staff of the International Monetary Fund as to the respective responsibilities of these twin Bretton Woods organisations in Washington, DC. It is time to call a halt to that kind of thing.

One very worrying aspect of the present state of the World Bank is that there is now a growing volume of arrears in servicing and meeting interest payments on some of its members' debts to it. Fifteen or 20 years ago, when I served on the board of the institution, that was virtually unheard of. Occasionally, one or two countries may have fallen briefly into arrears in meeting their interest payments on loans they had taken from the bank, but only temporarily, in most cases only a few days duration.

A very important aspect of the World Bank's operations was that it had no bad debts. That is important, although not merely because it is good for institutions not to have bad debts. The World Bank depends for its funds in part on contributions from countries such as Australia or, for that matter, its bigger members such as the United States, Japan, or the Federal Republic of Germany, who do provide capital from time to time, as this Bill provides. However, by far the greater source of the World Bank's funds for its very large volume of lending to developing countries is the world capital market. The World Bank borrows in its own right from those capital markets. It borrows in the United States, Switzerland and the Eurobond markets and anywhere it can find a market big enough to make it worth while borrowing. It has not yet borrowed in Australia; it has too many other competitors here in the shape-until very recently at least-of the Australian Government. But in undertaking those borrowings it is terribly important for the World Bank to be able to say, `This is our financial record; this is our balance sheet; this is our situation'. Once the arrears of interest payments start to show up in that financial record a question mark begins to be raised over the World Bank which was not there before and which does not stand well to it in the rates it can then command in those markets. Why should that be a matter of concern to us in one sense, if the World Bank begins to find some greater difficulties in undertaking borrowings in world markets?

We should never forget that all the member countries of the World Bank are its guarantors. If ever there were to come the day-I do not for one moment suggest that we are approaching or even getting within sight of that day, but one has to be long-sighted about these things-when the World Bank was unable to meet the repayments of the very large loans it has already borrowed in the international market, the member countries would have to foot the bill. Those member countries include Australia. That is why I take up a few minutes of the time of the Senate just to draw out these particular points.

I want to say, without spending undue time on it, that I agree with one element of the Bill which we are now debating-that is, that the Government has not on this occasion seen fit to take up the whole of its entitlement in new additional share capital in the bank which it would have been able to take up. It is appropriately prudent not to do so-almost unusually prudent, given the record of this Government in financial matters. I would go further to express the hope that the Government will not go further than it has decided to go.

Let me come to the other aspect of Senator Messner's amendment, which asks us to bear in mind the fact-and I underline those words-that through the bank Australia presumes to assist other economies. In the light of that fact the amendment expresses alarm at the Hawke Government's lack of concern or urgency in addressing Australia's emerging economic crisis, which is evident to all but the out of touch Mr Keating and Mr Hawke. Secondly, it further expresses concern at the collapse in family living standards since 1983 caused by a drop in purchasing power of at least $58 a week for families on average earnings. Thirdly, it urges the Hawke Labor Government to adopt policies to restore incentives to individuals to work and save and create job opportunities for their fellow Australians. Finally, it condemns the Hawke Labor Government for its abject failure to implement change in vital areas of the economy such as the labour market, shipping and the waterfront, affecting Australia's ability to pay off its debts, raise living standards and compete on world markets.

I would now like to address my remaining remarks to that aspect of Senator Messner's amendment. I might begin by asking myself the rhetorical question: What, in effect, would be the relevance of those matters to the Bill which we are presently debating in the Parliament? It is a Bill to provide extra capital to the World Bank on the part of one of its members, Australia. I do not think it takes very much thought to see the relevance of the final part of Senator Messner's amendment to that particular matter. How can any country which is itself going broke continue to provide hand-outs in foreign aid? How is that possible? I will tell honourable senators how it is possible. It can only do so by getting itself further into debt. Of course, it is open to us, as big-hearted people in the world, to incur more debts for Australians in order to provide funds for the World Bank or some other foreign aid recipient. But many Australians-and an increasing number of Australians, I would have to say to the Government-are questioning the wisdom of such a course at this time. They are beginning to say two things: first, that charity begins at home in any case; and, secondly, that we should begin to get our own house in order and until we have got our house in order we ought to be a great deal more restrained in the lavishness with which we go around the world providing funds to other countries, or other institutions in this case, at the expense of loading more debt on to our children.

Towards the end of January and at the beginning of February the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) spent 10 days travelling through four countries: Korea, Thailand, Pakistan and India. I happened to be in Japan when he was in Korea. I am not sure what he did there by way of hand-outs. Perhaps he did nothing. Korea is not a country which really is in need of hand-outs from Australia. Before very long the boot will be on the other foot, perhaps, if things carry on the way they are at the moment. If my memory serves me correctly, when Mr Hawke was in Thailand he handed out $35m to contribute to a bridge across the Mekong. When he was in Pakistan he handed out another $44m for assorted good works. When he was in India he committed one of Australia's agencies to providing another $60m, allegedly in that case in support of some export project. But it still comes on the back of the Australian taxpayer. So I think it is entirely proper for Senator Messner to express alarm at the fact that the Government seems to display so little urgency or concern about the present state in which this country finds itself.

It is well to remind ourselves that in this financial year we look like living beyond our means to the tune of $14 billion. That is not just my figure, my guess or my guesstimate. That is a figure put down by the Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia, Mr Paul Keating, in an interview with Michelle Grattan and published in the Melbourne Age last Monday. The Treasurer now thinks $14 billion will be the balance of payments deficit on the current account this financial year. The Senate does not need reminding that only six months earlier in his own Budget of last August the Treasurer was predicting that that figure would be $9.5 billion and that it would be falling from $12.3 billion of last year. Now it is rising from that figure of $12.3 billion to $14 billion, if indeed it can be contained to that figure.

People get impatient, quite rightly, with economists for all the jargon that they go on with-I find myself guilty of it from time to time, I must confess-when they talk about the balance of payments, the current account, the foreign debt and those things. But it is much easier to think about the situation of a family. When a family is living beyond its means there are only two ways it can do so. We all know this from our experience or the experience of friends or relatives. If a family is spending more than the income coming into the household will allow them to spend, there are only two ways they can do that. One is by getting into debt-getting a loan from the bank, a finance company, or perhaps a loan shark in the end. The other way in which they can finance living beyond their means is to sell something. If they happen to have a second car, they can sell it. If they get really desperate, they can sell their only car. Or they can sell off a paddock, if they happen to have one, or the wife's jewellery, if she happens to have any. If one is in a family situation, one can live beyond one's means only by borrowing, by getting into debt, or by selling things. It is exactly the same for a nation. Australia has been both borrowing and selling things now hand over fist under the present Government for almost precisely six years.

I remind the Senate that, when this Government came into office in early 1983, our net debt to foreigners-that is to say, our debts to foreigners less those debts which foreigners owed to us, including to our Reserve Bank-were less than $20 billion. Figures published only yesterday showed that at the end of December last year our net debt to foreigners had reached $95.4 billion; $95,402m, to be precise, according to the Australian Statistician. It had taken this country 195 years to accumulate net debts of less than $20 billion, from the time when Captain Phillip stepped ashore to 1983. But in the last six years we have accumulated further net debts of $75 billion. Under those circumstances, the message of Senator Messner's amendment, namely, that we cannot go on providing foreign aid in the way we are doing while at the same time going broke, is entirely apposite.

I said when I drew out the analogy about the family that there were two ways of financing a process of living beyond one's means. One of them is by borrowing. We have done that to the nth degree, as the figures I have just quoted would illustrate. The other way is by selling things, and under this Government's policies a lot of that has been going on, because it has had to. The Government itself has not been selling things. Perhaps it should have been more anxious to sell things. If we had a privatisation program, we might have seen some results. That is the program, you will recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, on which just after the last election the Prime Minister told us he was going to embark. He was taken away into a corner and spoken to kindly-or not so kindly-by members of his Party in the course of the next eight or nine months. Then when the Australian Labor Party foregathered for its biennial conference in Hobart in June of last year the whole privatisation program which the Prime Minister had raised was quietly tucked away, and we have heard no more of it since.

Australians have certainly been selling lots of things. Fortuitously, the annual report for 1987-88 of the Foreign Investment Review Board was published yesterday. That is a document which contains a certain amount of information about the process of selling off Australia which is now going on apace under the policies of this government and which is quite rightly creating a degree of concern in the community. When people see particularly major assets of this country falling into the hands of foreigners, they wonder what the future of this country is about and the future of their children. The first thing Australians have to understand about that is that one major reason why it is happening-not the only reason-is that when one lives beyond one's means, as this country is doing to the tune of $14 billion this year, according to the Treasurer, one has to either borrow or sell things, or both, which is what we are doing, in order to pay for it.

The Foreign Investment Review Board's annual report 1987-88, published yesterday, has a great deal of information on that subject. A table on page 19 of the report, which is entitled `The Level of Foreign Investment in Australia by Type of Investment', brings out the record of the Hawke Government in this area. Complete figures for 1987-88 are not yet available and will not be for some time until the Statistician completes his survey. Comparisons are provided in two fields from 30 June 1983-just after this Government came into office-to 30 June 1987. The first is the area of corporate equities, or share capital of companies. At 30 June 1983 foreign ownership of Australian corporate equities amounted to $27.1 billion. Four years later, at 30 June 1987, that figure had risen to $57.2 billion. Leaving aside some valuation effects because of the boom occurring on the stock exchange in June 1987, the fact is that there is a very large increase. In some ways, the more interesting figure is in the so-called `other' item, which includes all sorts of direct investment in factories, hotels and those sorts of things. In June 1983 total foreign ownership of that kind in Australia was valued at just over $16 billion, whereas by June 1987, only four years later, it had risen to $42.1 billion.

One should bear in mind that those figures for June 1987 are now nearly 20 months out of date and, as we all know, the pace of the growth of foreign ownership in Australia has stepped up considerably during that time to the point where it is becoming a matter of quite widespread public concern. Some of that public concern is misplaced, but in a general sense the public is correct to be concerned that under the policies of this Government we are selling off the country in order to go on living beyond our means because the Government will not take the action, or put into place policies, or even acknowledge the concern, which would be required to stop that happening. We therefore have a situation in which we are going broke. We are going further and further into debt, as those figures which I have quoted underline. We are selling off more and more of Australia, yet we continue to feel that nothing is wrong and that we can continue to provide funds of the kind provided in the Bill before us for this particular international financial agency.

What is the Government doing about this? My time will not allow me to address that subject adequately, but in Canberra this very day we have an indication of the kind of thing this Government thinks should be done about our present malaise. It has called a housing summit. Can we believe that? What a joke! The Premier of my State of Queensland, Mr Mike Ahern, early in January, if I recall correctly, floated the idea of a housing summit between the Commonwealth and the States to talk about the matter with some degree of seriousness. At the time, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer dismissed the idea as nonsense. I think they actually used that word. If they did not, they used some other perhaps more colourful word of the kind which Mr Keating, in particular, is so prone to use.

When the December quarter consumer price index figures were published on 31 January and the Treasurer, ashen-faced, had to contend with the clamour that arose out of those appalling figures, which showed that our inflation, far from coming down, was actually accelerating, he quickly got on the telephone to the Prime Minister in Karachi, or wherever he was at the time, and agreed that the thing to do was to call a housing summit, which is going on elsewhere in this building today. What do we find is on the agenda? What is the Government putting on the agenda of this housing summit, this major meeting which has brought together the Premiers of all six States, our Prime Minister, our Treasurer and goodness knows how many bureaucrats? There are two things that the Government has put on the agenda. First of all, it is going to sell off some previously unused land. I welcome that. The only question is: why has the Government not done it before? Why has it been the result of the December quarter consumer price index which has suddenly produced this flurry of activity on the part of the Government to sell off this previously unused land? Secondly, the Government is going to talk about local authority restrictions, in the form of various building regulations.

Again, I think that that is a perfectly proper subject for debate in the housing area, but is it really suggested that we need to have a meeting at prime ministerial level with all the Premiers to talk about that? It is nonsense. Of course, what the Government will not want to talk about is the level of interest rates which its policies have produced and which are killing mortgage holders in this country and it will not talk about the fact that its capital gains tax, which provides an exemption for the principal private residence, is producing a situation where more and more people are pouring more and more capital into the private residence because it is the only refuge they have left to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (General Capital Increase) Bill is a very significant one. Having read the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) and, more importantly, the recent press statements and other documents in this field I do not believe that the Government shares our commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner's amendment is very worth while because it notes that a thorough analysis of Australia's contribution to the World Bank is long overdue. It is clear in the Minister's second reading speech that we recognise that the bank has to adopt economic criteria that take a macro-economic view, that indeed there should not be lending to countries for long term structural adjustment purposes in the absence of a suitable framework of macro-economic policies for individual countries. I think that that is a commendable approach. It was one that commended itself to the United States Government, and certainly the current President of the World Bank, Mr Barber Conable, has frequently reiterated that that is a very important component of any aid program. I think that we are increasingly seeing that recognition by the bank and its staff. I think that that is desirable and hopefully the impact will flow through to the bank and its officials.

What I am concerned about principally today is that on the one hand we have a recognition in this country that things are deteriorating in the Third World, that there are significant economic as well as humanitarian benefits to Australia that can be derived from maintaining and increasing an official development assistance program that does include significant grants to international financial institutions, and yet on the other hand we have a mishmash of cynical political decisions that result in a downgrading of our contribution to the World Bank at this time.

It is perhaps significant to start with an article in the Australian Financial Review of 23 February last. The article described the visit of Mr Barber Conable to Australia and his specific criticism of Australia for its attitude to the Third World. Mr Conable stated:
It is your neighbourhood, where development is a matter of both opportunity and security for Australia now and into the future.
The article continued:

. . . referred specifically to Australia's refusal so far to take up its full share of the World Bank's third general capital increase, and overall reductions in the level of Australia's foreign aid under the Hawke Government.
The article stated:
`I am confident Australia will take up the general capital increase in full,' he said.
`But if it does not, then Australia will to a modest degree lost a percentage of its (voting) weight in the bank.'
The article pointed out:
Australia has made an initial payment of $3.6 million to the bank's general capital increase . . .

The current Bill would see an increase of almost $36m in our allocation. That would be a paid up contribution equivalent to about 3 per cent of the total of something of the order of $950m which would need to be available on a standby basis if the bank were ever to get into the sorts of difficulties that Senator Stone was talking about. What concerns me most of all is that in this article there are unnamed sources which indicate:

One of the Australian Government's principal objections to making its full contribution to the general capital increase involves the World Bank's environmental record, and mounting criticism among member countries that macro-economic reforms in poor countries are undertaken by the bank with little regard for environmental impact.

That is a disgraceful furphy. The fact of the matter is that the Australian Government has never made public criticisms of the World Bank for its environmental performance in recent times. I think that there is general understanding that the bank has not been as sensitive as it might have been in the past. There are a number of examples that one could give of areas where World Bank projects have gone ahead without concern for the environmental consequences. One could give instances of transmigration in Indonesia, the Narmada Valley Dam in India and the Electric Power Sector II loan in Brazil. There are a number of other examples where one could say quite accurately that the World Bank needed to get its act together, but the fact is that it is in the process of doing just that. It has increased its environmental staff some tenfold in the last few years. In 1987 it established a separate environmental department at its world headquarters and it created a further four environmental departments in major regional lending areas.

It follows that the bank has been susceptible to the criticism that has been made and it has adopted more stringent environmental criteria. This means that the snide suggestion in that article that somehow Australia is withholding funds because of environmental concerns is false and inaccurate and a disguise of the true economic reasons, which I will come to. No one has been game to stand up and say that in public; yet it is put forward in this backhand way as somehow an indication that we would really like to be on board, but there are some problems that we would like to see addressed first of all. They do not get a run in the Minister's second reading speech and, again, I think that is significant. The second reading speech states:

Australia is a strong, but not uncritical, supporter of the IBRD. We are concerned that the Bank maintains the high quality of its lending and continues to be cost effective. Australia has criticised the Bank when appropriate with the aim of improving its overall efficiency. In particular, Australia has expressed concerns about the very fast rate of growth of large scale fast disbursing structural adjustment loans, the growing incidence of arrears on Bank loans and the need to further enhance the Bank's work on environmental matters.

That is the only mention of environmental matters, and it comes a long way down the list. So the real concerns put forward are supposedly economic, supposedly the sorts of concerns that should have influenced many of the private sector banks before they embarked on those massive and ill-fated lending programs to the Third World and, in particular, to Latin America. But the fact is that Australia is putting forward at this time reasons which are simply not true. The environmental reason is a furphy and the concern about the World Bank's own lending programs I suggest is vastly overstated. The fact of the matter is this: what the Australian Government really has in mind is that in an election year, when it is desperate to cut back in as many areas as possible, it sees this as a cheap and easy option. For about the last 20 years the International Monetary Fund has kept economic indicators of relative performance on gross national product and they have indicated that Australia has provided contributions to the World Bank which have been consistently above what its strict obligations might have been on that relative gross national product (GNP) scale. At the moment it could be said that we should be contributing about 1.3 per cent of the bank's total capital, but in fact we currently provide 1.8 per cent. It is significant that 1.3 per cent is about 75 per cent of 1.8 per cent and that is precisely what we have offered to take up. We were allocated 10,734 shares; in this Bill we have agreed to take up 7,880 additional shares. There is the first very tangible piece of evidence that the real reason for Australia taking up only 75 per cent of its entitlement is that it now sees the opportunity to get back to its strict equivalent obligation after 20 years of letting it remain above the line. One could always argue that perhaps some people have to tighten their belts, but I categorically dispute the proposition that this Government is justified in undertaking that exercise at this time.

We know that the Government has embarked on massive cuts in official development assistance in recent years. When the Fraser Government left office the percentage of gross domestic product was in excess of 0.5 per cent. It was, in fact, around 0.55 per cent. The Australian contribution now languishes around 0.35 per cent, which is barely the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) Development Assistance Committee average. That in itself is deplorable. It has come about again because the Government has taken the view, quite cynically, that it could afford to make these massive cuts, that it could get away with them with minimal political pain in the electorate.
