The Government is aided and abetted by a disgraceful attitude on the part of the former Foreign Minister, who effectively volunteered cuts in Australia's official development assistance (ODA) contributions. I think it is fair to say that Australia now has, for the first time in six years, a Foreign Minister who at least has some sympathy and understanding for the aid community and the causes which it espouses; but, for all his bravado, braggadocio and bombast, he is still strangely lacking in courage when it comes to fighting for these constituents. I will soon come to a very significant speech of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) which I think blows that concern out of the water and exposes the Government's entirely parsimonious and niggardly attitude for what it is really worth.

What we have is a Government that now sees this as an opportune time to significantly reduce its contributions as a means of perhaps making a small gesture to the balance of payments deficit on current account which Senator Stone talked about earlier. It is simply in desperate financial difficulties. The credibility of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is in tatters. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is acutely aware that his own constituency will not allow any significant privatisation, any significant asset sales, any significant reduction in expenditure in the April statement. As a result, the Government is very keen to cut costs wherever possible.
It is a matter of deep regret that there is an obvious conflict of interest in the position of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. He has been mouthing such soothing noises as:
I very much wish the overall aid budget was higher and I will push for that . . .
He said that shortly after taking office, in an interview published in the Melbourne Age on 9 September 1988. However, he went on to say:
. . . although `as a member of the expenditure review committee, I'm acutely conscious of the need to reduce government spending.'

That is an outrage. One should not have the same Minister urging increases on the one hand and urging reductions on the other. It is an appalling situation. It calls for the Minister to stand aside from the Expenditure Review Committee when aid matters are under consideration. It certainly requires him to adopt a dramatically different attitude to that of his predecessor, who was prepared to sacrifice the interests of Australia's international reputation and its overseas development assistance budget, who had taken the view that, by and large, aid was a waste of time, that most of the infrastructure projects that Australia had undertaken were simply not performing, and who threw in the towel.

I do not think Senator Evans is at that stage. Unfortunately, on the one hand he would like to be more generous; on the other he knows that he will be chopped off at the knees if he does anything courageous. As a result, he is not going to achieve the sorts of increases that his wish list suggests or that he has been talking about to various groups in recent months.
The Australian Government is now prepared to agree to an increase of some $36m in our contribution. But the Minister's speech says:
The Government has not decided whether Australia will subscribe to its remaining entitlement of 2,854 GCI shares or relinquish them for allocation to other members of the Bank.

In other words, no policy decision has been taken or, if it has, it has not been officially announced. There is no reason why Australia should not agree to take up its additional entitlement. I agree entirely with what Senator Messner and others have had to say about taking a more active role in the forums of the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and other financial institutions.

I do not subscribe to the view that aid should be given without strings, but I take the view that we are entitled to see where our money goes, to ensure that we get value and that policies are not put into place as a result of those loans which are antipathetic to the economic environment that we believe will be most conducive to growth. I think there are obligations that attach to our contributions at the present time. Increased obligations should attach to increased contributions. I regard it as regrettable in the extreme that the Government seems to be obsessed with the short term financial situation in which it finds itself and is prepared to take this cheap and cynical way out with no regard at all for those in the developing countries whose needs are infinitely greater than ours.

I do not subscribe to the nostrum that charity begins at home because implicitly it means that charity ends at home. I think it is a dishonest attitude. It is simply an excuse for putting a circle around our part of the world and ignoring the plight of others. I do not believe we should ever reach that situation. The Fraser Government had a very proud and enviable track record. Under this Government foreign aid has become a man made disaster of massive proportions. It is an absolute disgrace. There is absolutely no justification for the sorts of cuts that we have seen in recent years. The reduction of something like 12 per cent in 1987 was simply not warranted by the economic circumstances of the time any more than it might have been warranted throughout the entire period the Hawke Government has been in office.

Yet the Government has taken the view that it can make these arbitrary and selective cuts because somehow the electorate is more obsessed with its own concerns. That does not do Australia's reputation much good. It ignores the fact that 90 per cent of our bilateral assistance is provided in the form of Australian goods and services and that there are very significant economic and commercial benefits that derive from an enlightened official development assistance program. It gives us a great deal of influence that quite often will assist in opening trade doors around the world.

One only has to look at the Japanese approach. The Japanese are certainly not motivated by altruism and yet their percentage of ODA has risen in recent years quite significantly. It is now about 0.31 per cent. I can recall when it was about 0.15 per cent.

Of the 18 member countries of the Development Assistance Committee of the OECD seven have actually increased their percentages of aid since 1982, whilst Australia's ODA has fallen from 0.55 to 0.35 per cent. No other country has seen effectively a 40 per cent reduction as we have in Australia. In other words, Australia is now a world leader in cutting back on its foreign assistance. This further reduction in our obligations to the World Bank does not derive from any professed or synthetic concern about the World Bank getting its house in order; it derives entirely from the Government's belief that it can get away with cuts in this area.

I now come to what I regard as a very sad commentary on the sorts of motivations and inspirations that seem to drive the newly appointed Foreign Minister. I am prepared to concede that Senator Evans has had a longstanding interest in foreign affairs and I regard him as someone who has a degree of sympathy in the area and who is attuned to the needs of Third World countries. Unfortunately, because of the pressures of the office and, no doubt, colleagues such as the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) he has entirely succumbed to the `cuts mentality'. Senator Evans gave a speech to the Ideas Centre in Sydney on 17 November 1988 which is very significant because in it he purported to set out some of the problems that beset the Third World, and then looked at Australia's situation. He said:
. . . the sustained boom in the US . . . has brought very few benefits to developing countries.
Quoting from the report World Nutrition Situation issued by the United Nations in November 1987, he said:
. . . since the early 80s widespread economic recession and droughts in Africa have reversed this trend.
He was referring there to global improvements in nutrition. He continued:
. . . the situation has worsened in many countries.
Quoting from the World Development Report 1988, he said:

Poverty in the developing countries is on the rise. Between 1970 and 1980 the number of people with inadequate diets in developing countries . . . increased from 650 million to 730 million. Since 1980 matters have turned from bad to worse.
Having adopted those comments, Senator Evans said:
According to estimates from the International Labour Organisation, the number of people living in extreme poverty in developing countries increased from 819 million in 1980 to 881 million in 1985.
So he is acknowledging the enormity of the problem in the Third World. He continued:
. . . developing countries have been plunged into a debt crisis that is still very much with us.
The third aspect of the boom to note-
that is, in the United States-
is that it is hard to believe that it can last.
. . . the American dollar will slide, and world interest rates will tend to rise.
Unfortunately, the likelihood is that all of this will be bad news for developing countries. Developing countries will probably lose in two ways: world commodity prices are likely to fall . . .

I acknowledge that that is not very good news for Australia either because it has been the basis on which the Treasurer's whole Budget strategy has been framed in recent years. It has been the soft option that we have consistently taken to justify not taking the hard cuts in expenditure. Senator Evans went on to say:
. . . world commodity prices are likely to fall, and interest rates are likely to again rise. These trends will make worse their debt burdens . . .
He was referring to the debt burdens of Third World countries. He continued:
. . . it is hard to see how world economic trends during the next three or four years are likely to help developing countries at all.

So there is an explicit acknowledgment and concession that the plight of the Third World is deteriorating rapidly and there is no prospect of improvement. I simply ask in passing: Does the Minister consider that Australia's position will deteriorate or not improve over the next three or four years? If he does, that is a concession of defeat which I welcome because it means that any economic credibility that attached to this Government is now out the window. So I presume that this Government does not take that view. In fact, it argues that our economic position will improve. So, vis-a-vis the Third World, we have a much increased capacity to contribute. So there it is. On the one hand, we have an increasing need in the Third World and, on the other hand, we have an increasing capacity to pay. We all love user pays, so we can afford to do something about that; that is what Senator Evans is saying. He went on to say:
Closer to home, in Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific, growth is needed as well. Indeed, in many countries close to Australia income per head has actually been falling in recent years.
So there we have it. There is the need and there is Australia's capacity to pay. What do we find when Senator Evans defines Australia's aid objectives? This is very enlightening:
First and foremost, Australia's aid effort is founded on the commitment of the Australian population to basic humanitarian concerns . . .
That is perfectly acceptable and admirable. He continued:
Within that humanitarian framework it should come as no surprise for me to say that the primary objective of Australian aid is to promote growth and economic development in developing countries.
I am surprised because in Budget Paper No. 4 the Minister had this to say in the foreword:
The principal objective of the Australian aid program is to promote the economic and social advancement of the peoples of developing countries . . .

In other words, since Senator Evans has taken over this portfolio, social concern is no longer a matter that is regarded as an objective of the aid program. It is simply about economics. He went on to say in his address:
While the development objective is the most important, it is by no means the only goal of our aid program. Another is to advance or reinforce Australian political and strategic objectives.

Pretty naked stuff! We do not find that in Budget Paper No. 4. I have never seen it in Ministers' statements in the past. I always recall Andrew Peacock being very sensitive at suggestions that aid was an instrument of foreign policy, yet that is a much more respectable view than simply putting as the second object of our aid program `to advance or reinforce Australia's political and strategic objectives'. In other words, is there a vote in it? Senator Evans went on to say:
A third main objective is commercial.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has nothing to do with votes.
—It has nothing to do with votes? It has a lot to do with cutting costs, as I was saying before Senator Tate arrived.
—So you agree with me? It has nothing to do with votes.
—Overseas aid?
—No, the second objective.

—I certainly do not. It is `to advance or reinforce Australia's political objectives'. I would have thought that Australia's political objectives were to enhance its standing and reputation and, hopefully, to pass that on to the Australian community to be reflected in increased votes. Perhaps we can discuss what Australia's political objectives are a little later.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact remains that, on reading Senator Evans's very important address on aid, it is quite clear that he is obsessed only with economic and political objectives. Perhaps the most disappointing thing of all is that Senator Evans says, `I have only just come into the job but I think I will give you a bit of a run down on the way I see things and the way in which I think our aid program should proceed'. Having made the right genuflection in the direction of non-government organisations and quite properly acknowledging that they are a very cost efficient means of providing assistance, he says, `Here is my forward agenda. It is a little premature but I just thought I would give you a sketch of the main priorities. First, I would like to see a steady increase in the volume of aid, both in dollar terms and as a proportion of GNP. I am concerned that we are slipping back, both in absolute terms and relative to other major aid donors, and I would certainly like to see a significant movement in the aid ratio back towards at least 0.4 per cent within the next few Budgets'. What outrageous and sanctimonious nonsense because he then went on to say in his address that it was all going to be too difficult. He said:

Just to maintain aid at 0.36% of GNP would, on present estimates, require the allocation of another $39 million, and to increase the proportion to 0.37% will require another $72 million. So it is going to be hard to even maintain the present ratio, let alone get any major improvement in it, but I am hopeful that we will be able to at least start moving in this direction.

There is not even a commitment to maintain aid as a proportion of gross national product when the Government has slashed that percentage from 0.55 per cent to 0.36 per cent in the space of six years. There is not even a commitment to maintain that disastrously low level. There is the sort of real commitment that the Minister gives. He starts off by saying, `We need a steady increase. I would like to see it go up', but, as we know, he is a member of the Expenditure Review Committee and he will be allowed to do nothing of the sort. So there it is; an absolutely worthless commitment. He also said in his address:
My second priority is to encourage other developed nations to expand their aid programs as well.

He is saying, `We will not do much about it but we will go around the world lecturing others to boost their commitments', when, as I have indicated, seven of the 18 countries have already increased their percentage over that period and Australia has reduced its proportion by 40 per cent. What we have are sanctimonious double standards and unctuous rubbish. What that means is that we will spend our time jawboning rather than contributing. Senator Evans continued:
Australia should, as a matter of policy, work to combat so-called `aid-fatigue'.

That is another pathetic cop-out. The community in Australia presently contributes about $60m a year to non-government organisations. That sum has not fallen in recent years despite the disgraceful cutbacks in official development assistance. It is quite clear that there is still a high level of concern. More than one million Australian citizens belong to something approaching 100 organisations interested in the field of voluntary aid, yet this Government talks about aid fatigue. The only aid fatigue is on the part of this Government which sees it as a cheap and cynical opportunity to get out of its obligations, to cut back or to reduce its Budget deficit. I regard that as a deplorable situation.

Senator Evans's third major objective is to promote `an open world trading environment'. Wonderful stuff! Mr Dawkins got off to a good start with the Cairns Group and Mr Duffy is pursuing it. Let them do their thing. That is important, but it has very little to do with any justification for Australia continuing to reduce its official aid program. It certainly has nothing to do with providing any justification for the continued refusal to increase our contribution to the World Bank. I, therefore, regard this Bill as a very regrettable indictment of the Australian Government's attitude to the Third World and to international financial institutions and as a concession to moral and intellectual bankruptcy. It is quite clear that this Government does not even recognise the very tangible and substantial benefits to which the Minister's second reading speech pays lip service. It waxes eloquent about the substantial benefits from aid, including political benefits dependent on developmental effectiveness, and on the commercial benefits that derive. Let me give one small example in passing of the Government's deplorably cynical approach. In Budget Paper No. 4 refugees are singled out as a very important area of concern. Twenty million dollars is set aside to assist Afghan refugees. Not 1c of that money has been paid and not 1c will be paid in this financial year because of the state of flux in Afghanistan. So the linchpin of its refugee assistance is on hold, which is typical. It is saving $20m in that field alone, yet the Government is not prepared to make the sort of increases that Barber Conable has urged, that the rest of the international community recognises as essential, and it is not even prepared to give the Australian community the real reasons for our disgraceful backdown.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (General Capital Increase) Bill 1988, in respect of which my colleague Senator Messner has moved quite a lengthy amendment, which I shall not read out. I intend to address the third part of that amendment to this motion. In the first part of this amendment Senator Messner has referred to the alarm which he and many other senators have at this Government's lack of concern or urgency in addressing Australia's emerging economic crisis. I do not think that anyone can doubt that at the present moment this nation is facing an economic crisis of dramatic proportions.

SPEECH.PARA: I seem to recall when I was in this chamber in 1981-82 some of the speeches of Senator Walsh in his vitriolic attacks on the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, and the economic record of the Fraser Government during 1981-82. I look back today at some of those speeches, and it is very interesting to see why Senator Walsh is now looking so tired, worn and exhausted as he wanders around this place. For example, on 9 March 1982 he referred to the claim by Mr Fraser that external influences were responsible for failures. He claimed that that was not so.

He went on to talk about unemployment at almost record levels, inflation back in double figures, growth down, record interest rates, record levels of taxation and a balance of payments crisis. What is the situation at the moment? Unemployment is at record levels. Let me tell the Senate that average monthly unemployment under the Fraser Government was 403,000. Under the Hawke Government it is 627,000, which is an increase of almost 50 per cent. Yet back in 1982 Senator Walsh was talking about unemployment at almost record levels and being critical of this. I might mention the disgraceful monthly youth unemployment levels now running at 130,000 under this Government.
I look at other speeches of Senator Walsh in those years. He talked about interest rates in a speech made on 1 April 1981. He said:

I refer now to interest rates. It has recently become apparent from a wide variety of sources that the prevailing interest rate for overdrafts above $100,000 is 16.5 per cent. This is without precedent.

It might have been without precedent in 1981; it is certainly very common in 1989. It is far in excess of that. Senator Walsh, in a speech made on 29 April 1981, talked about foreign investment. He said:
What is being questioned in this debate is the rate at which foreign capital is coming into this country and also the type of foreign capital which is coming into the country.

I refer the Senate to the type of capital and the rate at which capital is coming into this country at present. What has happened to the economy is that this Labor Government has in fact mortgaged this country to the hilt. We are now in debt to the tune of $120 billion and we are going down the drain at the rate of $50m a day. Having mortgaged our future, this Government is now adopting a policy of selling off this country's assets in order to attempt, in some way or other, to overcome the massive debt which increases every day.

The reason Senator Walsh is looking so tired is that he clearly recognises that he has failed. He has been the Minister for Finance in this Government for six years. He has been talking for six years about micro-economic reform and macro-economic changes in order to turn the economy around. Instead of managing to turn the economy around, what has happened under the administration of his Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, his Treasurer, Mr Keating, and himself is that the economy has taken a massive downturn. Senator Walsh cannot blame outside forces because the truth is that commodity prices overall have never been at a higher rate. In fact, this is the only thing which is stopping this country from falling into a massive abyss. The prices we are obtaining for our wool, wheat and exported primary produce are now at record levels. Our revenue from the tourism industry is at a world high. It is that revenue which is stopping us from falling into the abyss of a depression, the like of which has not been seen since the 1930s. That is why there is massive fear among economists and those who have applied their minds to these problems as to what will happen to this country if there is any fall in world commodity prices. Of course, as the United States of America addresses its economic problems, the possibility of there being a fall in world commodity prices should cause us to be fearful of our position in 1989.

I think that Senator Walsh now realises after six years as Minister for Finance, after six years of beating his head against the brick wall of the Australian Labor Party-preventing micro-economic reform, failing to fix up the problems of transport, the waterfront, shipping, Telecom or the government business enterprises and notwithstanding the rhetoric of the last May statement-that his contribution to economic recovery has been no more than if he had stayed at home in Western Australia and grown wheat. In fact, if he had managed to grow more wheat in Western Australia for export, that would have probably been of greater value to Australia's economy than his efforts have been as Minister for Finance.

I am pleased to see that I have perhaps persuaded Senator Walsh to come into the chamber to hear me say that he would have been better staying home in Western Australia growing wheat for the last six years than to have beaten his head against the brick wall of the Labor Party in relation to the micro-economic changes which still need to be made after six years of this Labor Government.

Interest rates in this country are at higher levels now than in 1981-82. In addition, the prices of homes have risen such that, on my calculations, a median priced existing home now costs about $111,000 and home loan repayments as a percentage of income have increased by 30.7 per cent. Looking at the cost of an ordinary basket of goods, one sees why the women's vote has turned against the Labor Party. Women know what it costs them when they go shopping. On my calculations, since March 1983 the cost of an absolute minimum basic food basket has risen by about 44 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Forty-four?

—Since this Government took office in March 1983 it has risen by 44 per cent. In the meantime, our overseas debt has increased at the rate of $50m a day. For some reason or other some commentators seem to have fallen for Mr Keating's line that he has a clever policy of devaluing the dollar. I think one journalist talked about walking the dollar down. No country which is successful in its economic activities has a declining dollar. Under the Hawke Government the value of the Australian dollar has fallen by 55 per cent against the Japanese yen, 30 per cent against the deutschmark, 22 per cent against the United Kingdom pound, and 28 per cent against the trade weighted index. Devaluing the dollar is not a solution to our economic problems. It may assist some of our exporters but it increases our overseas debt and our difficulties in meeting interest payments on that overseas debt.
—And raises inflation.

—And, as my colleague Senator Messner says, it raises inflation substantially. It is no solution. If it were a solution to the economic problems of a country, Venezuela would be a substantial economic success. Instead, it is reported today that there has been a 60 per cent rise in the cost of certain goods, including basic items such as petrol, and rioting in the streets as the result of a recent 40 per cent devaluation of its currency.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, that is no solution to our problem. On the contrary, what we need is a steadily rising dollar value-not brought about by high interest rates, which is the Government's other policy, but by very substantial economic reform, including micro-economic reform. As Senator Walsh knows, in many respects macro-economic reform-trying to look at interest rates, inflation, the big figures-is like squeezing a balloon. If the balloon is squeezed too tight in one direction it expands in another direction. What is needed is to get down to the basics. The Government has deregulated the financial market and we have congratulated it on that. However, it desperately needs to deregulate the labour market, not so that wages can fall-we are not talking about lowering people's wages-but so we can create fluidity in the labour market. Thus people can move from one job to another in order to obtain better wages in areas in which we need increased productivity and get out of those jobs which are not economically worthwhile. The Government needs to apply its mind to those areas and also to that of privatisation.

I acknowledge, on the credit side, that under this Government there has been, as Mr Keating claims, an increase in the number of jobs. I think he claims 1.2 million jobs. I give the Government credit for that, but I wonder what the reasons are for that increase. I suggest that in many ways it goes back to the breaking of the drought shortly after the Hawke Government came to office in 1983 and the wage pause of the Fraser Government during its last year of office. It is certainly related to the very substantial increase in the number of immigrants and refugees this country takes. The annual intake has doubled. Under the Hawke Government there has been a substantial population increase and that has been a major reason for the increase in the number of jobs.

The real truth is that the Government has hocked this nation for an additional $75 billion. That is the real cost of those 1.2 million jobs. As I said before, this Government has mortgaged our assets to finance its policies and it is now selling off those assets to foreign investors as we are unable to keep meeting the insurance commitments.

TALK.START.PARA: —They went down the soft option road.

—I thoroughly agree with Senator Messner. What happened-much to the horror of Senator Walsh-is that this Government went down the soft option route. It will continue to do so because of its relationship with the trade union movement. How can it face up to the trade union movement when it is locked into an accord as a result of which wages will rise in all industries across the nation, regardless of their productivity and profitability and the state of the economy? Wages will rise across the board. I am not opposed to wage rises where a company is profitable and increases in productivity are needed. Under this Government's very tight taxation policies-they are such that people now pay 40c in the dollar on any income they earn above the average weekly wage-there is no encouragement for people to endeavour to work a little harder to earn money in overtime. This nation's living standards have fallen dramatically.

SPEECH.PARA: Within the past 10 days the value of the Australian dollar has fallen by about 10 or 12 per cent. Senator Walsh, who is here, has the accurate figures. He is the Minister for Finance, not me, so he will no doubt tell the Senate what the dollar has fallen to; but it has fallen by about 10 per cent. That means that the assets of all Australians have been devalued by 10 per cent. It also means that our overseas debt has increased by about that figure and that our difficulty in meeting the interest payments on it has increased by about 10 per cent. Senator Walsh may enter into some argument as to detail and say that I have not got it quite right, but the truth is that the dollar falling in that way has created great difficulties for us in meeting our payments.

The Government still talks about the dollar falling. I do not want to speculate on that, but while we continue to have an overseas trade deficit of about $50m a day, of course the dollar will fall. What we are doing is maintaining our living standards by borrowing money. We all know that if one wants to live on an annual income of, say, $40,000 a year and is earning only $25,000 a year, one can live at the standard of $40,000 by borrowing $15,000 a year. One can do that so long as one's assets keep allowing one to borrow the additional $15,000 a year. But sooner or later one will run out of an equity which will enable one to continue to borrow that additional money to live the way one wishes to live. When that happens there is disaster.

This country faces a massive foreign debt. Commodity prices, although high at the moment, have little chance of substantially increasing. Tourism is booming and bringing in substantial income, but there is no chance of seeing an economic turnaround for four or five years at the earliest, if it is possible. As I have said, under this Government the country is being mortgaged to the hilt. The Government is not taking the urgent measures which are desperately needed to rectify the problems. Until it does, we will continue to attack the Government and to expose its bluff and rhetoric.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, clause 3, before the definition of ``Bank'', insert the following new definitions:
`` `affiliates' means the Association and the Corporation;
`Association' means the International Development Association established under the Articles of Agreement set out in the Schedule to the International Development Association Act 1960;''.
Page 1, clause 3, after the definition of ``Bank'', insert the following new definition:
`` `Corporation' means the International Finance Corporation established under the Articles of Agreement referred to in section 3 of the International Finance Corporation Act 1955.''.
Page 2, after clause 6, add the following new clause:
Annual Report

``7. (1) As soon as practicable after the end of each financial year the Treasurer shall prepare and cause to be laid before each House of the Parliament a report on the operations of this Act during that financial year.
``(2) Without limiting the generality of subsection (1), the report shall include:
(a) a statement of the terms and conditions of any agreement or agreements made by the Treasurer with the Bank for the purchase by Australia of any additional shares under this Act;
(b) a statement describing the nature and extent of Australia's participation as a member of the Bank and the affiliates during that year;
(c) an assessment of the activities and effectiveness of the Bank and the affiliates, including their activities and effectiveness in relation to:
(i) the alleviation of poverty;
(ii) the prevention of damage to the environment; and
(iii) obtaining, and taking into account, the views and needs of indigenous peoples,
in countries affected by the activities of the Bank and the affiliates.''.

As I pointed out during the second reading debate, the amendments are directed towards an annual report. We believe there is a chronic lack of regular and detailed information about Australia's participation in the World Bank. I was interested to note that Senator Watson detailed that objection during his contribution to the second reading debate. The problems we have are a lack of information and particularly, as I said in the second reading debate, our desire to know precisely where the development philosophy of the World Bank is going. Basically we are looking at: what goals is Australia pursuing through the World Bank; how effective is participation in the bank as a means of getting our development assistance goals, the ones promoted by the Australian Government; to what extent do our own bilateral aid projects through the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) link up with World Bank projects through co-financing mechanisms; to what extent do we promote opportunities for Australians to act as consultants for the World Bank and encourage Australian companies to tender for World Bank projects; how well is the bank carrying out the development tasks that the Australian community believes it should carry out; what sort of contributions do Australian representatives make towards the development of the bank's policy; and so on?

All of these items of information, we believe, ought to be able to be made available to the Australian public through an annual report. At the moment we have some reporting mechanisms. As I said in my earlier speech, there is the annual report of the Treasury, there are the associated August Budget Papers on Australia's overall development program, and, of course, there are the annual reports of Australia's dealings in the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD). That latter report comes through the annual report which is required under the International Monetary Agreements Act 1947. Unfortunately only very basic information on the structure of the IBRD-which this Bill, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (General Capital Increase) Bill, deals with-and the other affiliates is provided in those reports. They provide information on the Australian membership and on the broad financial developments. The subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, in its current investigation of AIDAB, has taken a particular interest in this and asked Treasury to provide it with considerable detail on the conduct of policy towards the World Bank. It seems to me that it exemplifies the problem that that material has to be requested by a committee of the chambers because it is not readily available.

We believe that what we should be doing is putting together a much more reasonable and substantive exercise. I refer particularly to the two letters that were sent to the World Bank in the last two years-Senator Messner was one of the signatories-directed towards those items which I raised in my second reading debate, that is, the alleviation of poverty, acting to prevent environmental degradation, and ensuring that the World Bank's programs take into account the views and needs of indigenous people.

We believe that an annual report to parliament, assessing the World Bank's work in these areas, would be of great benefit to those senators and members who signed those letters. If we look at the signatories, particularly to the second letter, we find that they were: Senator Alston, Senator Archer, Senator Aulich, Senator Peter Baume, Senator Michael Baume, Senator Beahan, Senator Chaney, and Senator Hill, who was instrumental in putting those letters together. There were also Australian Labor Party, Australian Democrats and independent members. There was certainly such a depth of interest in an activity quite outside the normal activities that go on in this chamber that a number of members and senators were sufficiently interested to work together and co-sign a letter to the World Bank. Obviously the annual report, set out in the terms I have suggested, would be read and used by members and senators interested in this area. I take the point that Senator Watson made, that this is not something we should go into lightly and that the various topping up exercises that we have undertaken with the World Bank, particularly with the arms of the World Bank, ought to be ones on which this Parliament makes an informed judgment which would need to go beyond Treasury's report or the annual report provided under the International Monetary Agreements Act.

It is interesting to note in this regard the increased activity in the American Congress. Senator Watson referred to this in his speech in the second reading debate. In consultation with the secretaries of Treasury and State, a list of the loans likely to have an adverse effect on the environment, natural resources, public health or indigenous people is required to be compiled, and this list is to be prepared and updated semiannually in consultation with members of the public. That is what the United States Congress has required of its executive. I believe we should do no less, particularly with regard to our standing in this area and our support for the World Bank.

I think there are excellent reasons why such an annual report which goes more into the development philosophy ought to be presented to parliament. I believe it will not be the type of report that floats through and is not read by members because, as I have already demonstrated by quoting from those two letters sent by so many members of this and the other chamber, there is a depth of interest in this Parliament on these matters. I think the information which is currently provided by the World Bank to various government departments would make the compilation of such a report a relatively easy task. In looking as I have at the information which is provided to the government departments on an unclassified basis, it is fairly obvious that the task of putting that information into an annual report would be relatively easy. I think the enhanced flow of information to members of parliament could make for far more informed debates about what I believe is a very important item of our international responsibilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will be supporting the amendments moved by the Australian Democrats on this matter. In the various speeches on the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (General Capital Increase) Bill, especially that of my colleague Senator Watson, we have consistently made the point that there is a need for continual oversight by the Australian Government of the operations of the World Bank. The other point I raise-it is in the form of a question to the Minister-is whether there is any need for this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't think so.

—Perhaps if the Minister answers this question he may be able to put it to rest. The initial Bretton Woods agreements were given legislative sanction by this Parliament I believe back in 1947, by the passage of the International Monetary Agreements Act, and there was a requirement in that legislation for an annual report. Perhaps the Minister could advise us whether that is so and whether the guidelines and principles by which that annual report was required to be submitted and drawn up are still in force or whether they have merely atrophied or disappeared into the blue smoke somewhere in the system. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just answering Senator Messner's question at this stage. Therefore I am speaking only about the third amendment, that is, the amendment concerning the annual report. As I said by way of interjection, the Government does not believe there is any need for this amendment for the following reasons: the Treasurer already reports annually to the Parliament, as required by the International Monetary Agreements Act 1947, on the operations of that Act and the operations of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund during each financial year as they relate to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This report focuses mainly on our financial relationship with the bank and fund but also contains more general information, for example information on the roles of the two institutions and on Australian procurement and cofinancing with them, and copies of the communique issued after the meetings of governors. In addition, the Treasurer releases copies of his plenary statements at bank and fund meetings and provides further information on the bank through his replies to parliamentary questions. Specific press releases can be made when necessary on particular issues. Having said that, I am advised by the present Treasurer (Mr Keating) that it may be possible to provide somewhat more information in the report to parliament under the International Monetary Agreements Act.

I suppose it is a matter of judgment as to whether there is any need to go further than that. But even if there is a judgment that it is desirable to go further than that, I do not think it is an appropriate amendment. The first couple of paragraphs are arguably superfluous anyway in view of what I have just said. There is a request for a statement by the Treasurer on the terms and conditions of any agreements, and statements describing the nature and extent of Australia's participation as a member of the bank and its affiliates during the year. I certainly argue that those two paragraphs are superfluous because that is adequately covered under the reporting requirements of the 1947 Act.

When we move further down the amendment, we see it requires the Treasurer to report on the activities and effectiveness of the bank and its affiliates, including its activities and effectiveness in relation to the alleviation of poverty. Last night the coalition and all the Democrats voted for the amendment to section 46.

ANSWER.PARA: Put simply, as a result of that amendment to section 46, where, at any time between September 1985 and January 1988, the ownership of a partnership, company assets or shares have been rearranged pursuant to a marriage dissolution-one partner having been effectively bought out or having withdrawn assets from the company or partnership-the remaining shareholders or partners will now be subject to capital gains taxation whenever they sell the business, shares or assets. In other words, because of that amendment-if it is accepted by the Government in the House of Representatives; I do not know what the Treasurer intends to do about it-a retrospective liability will be imposed on completely innocent people who made such arrangements regarding the ownership of a business in that period of about 28 months for reasons which had absolutely nothing to do with an intention to avoid taxation.

I have been asked by Senator Maguire in what cases there may be justification for application of retrospective liability. I suggest that in that case there was certainly no justification. There are other cases in which in my view there has been a justification. I refer, for example, to the tax evasion or avoidance scheme known as the cherry pickers scheme, the most notorious practitioners of which were two sleazy characters known as the Kelly brothers. For years, they had been paying into a superannuation fund and claiming for those payments deductions from their company's taxable incomes, ostensibly for the benefit of their employees. At the same time they carefully arranged their work force so that no employee ever qualified to receive the benefits from the superannuation fund into which payments were being made, ostensibly for their benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. The Minister has meandered around this subject endlessly in the past. My point of order, however, is that the answer has ceased to be relevant. The Minister has answered the question asked by Senator Maguire. I made the point at the beginning of Question Time that shorter answers should be given. On several days this week, 10 or a dozen questions were asked. I ask you to call the Minister to order and sit him down.
—The Minister must not debate the question. It is a very long answer. I ask him to take that into account.

—I am just about to finish, Mr President. An attempt was made in 1986, I think, to recover from this pair of crooks known as the Kelly brothers the money they had filched from the Australian taxpayers. All of the Australian Democrats and all members of the coalition voted against that attempt to impose a tax liability through the backdating of legislation. The entire coalition and all of the Democrats last night voted to impose a retrospective liability on completely innocent people.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. It results from an answer, or perhaps non-answer, which Senator Tate gave Senator Lewis the other day when he said he was not prepared to give any answer in relation to the report from the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) which was to be given to the Ministerial Council yesterday. As we have read in the papers, this has been done. Does the Government approve of the decision of the NCSC, as revealed in proceedings in the Victorian Supreme Court in January this year, to a deal with Rothwells Ltd to stop the NCSC's 1987 investigation into that company? Does it also approve of the later decision of the NCSC, at the request of the Dowding Government, not to make public the fact that it had been looking into what the Chairman, Mr Bosch, has described as a market manipulation antic?

—The position of the Federal Government in relation to the whole Rothwells matter has been outlined by me and by the Attorney-General in another place, over many weeks late last year and into the first days of this session. Basically, what has been indicated is that under the current arrangements the National Companies and Securities Commission is answerable to the Ministerial Council, which comprises the Attorneys from all Australian jurisdictions, including obviously, those from jurisdictions in which the government is formed by the conservative parties. That line of responsibility was best exemplified yesterday when the National Companies and Securities Commission made its report to the Ministerial Council which decided, on the basis of a request from Western Australia, to appoint a special investigator to look at the matters of real concern which had been identified and foreshadowed as serious matters by Mr Bosch. I believe that we can have great confidence in the integrity and experience of the Queen's Counsel who has been selected--
—Very slow.

—Senator Hill interjects, `Very slow'. The whole purpose of appointing this QC, as was the case for the Ariadne investigation, is to speed up the process and to ensure that the expertise is available.
—You were told at the airport that the resources were adequate.

—The resources were adequate to the point where the investigation could be undertaken by the NCSC itself. It has now reached a stage where, quite clearly, the special skills of the QC who has been selected to carry out the special investigation, Mr Malcolm McCusker--
—Either you are covering up or you are just incompetent; one or the other.

—I do not accept that. The fact is that the Ministerial Council takes responsibility for the direction of the NCSC. It has now agreed to the appointment of that prominent Perth QC to carry out the special investigations and no doubt prosecutions may be expected as a result of those investigations. An independent QC's opinion will be sought on the question of whether that report to the Ministerial Council might be made available in a parliamentary forum, namely, the Western Australian Parliament. If that is made available in a way which will not prejudice any possible future prosecutions, I believe that many of the honourable senator's fears and misgivings might be allayed. He will be able to see the report, if it is possible, and the basis on which the special investigator has been appointed. I believe that the NCSC, under the supervision of the Ministerial Council, will be found to have acted quite properly in these matters.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Unfortunately, Senator Tate's long answer had absolutely nothing to do with the question I asked. I repeat the question: it was public knowledge in January this year as a result of proceedings in the Supreme Court of Victoria; and we did not need to wait until yesterday to know about it. Does the Government, which wants to take over the control of companies, approve of the decision of the NCSC to do a deal with Rothwells, the effect of which was to stop NCSC investigation into Rothwells and its associated companies from about November 1987?
—I have no further comment on the matters that have been raised.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WOMEN IN INDUSTRY: CONTRACEPTION AND HEALTH

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I draw the Minister's attention to the recent advice received by the organisation, Women in Industry: Contraception and Health-known as WICH-that it will not be receiving a grant-in-aid from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in 1988-89. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the basis for this decision and of the options that WICH has to seek other sources of support?

—The Women in Industry: Contraception and Health organisation has received a great deal of support from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs since 1983. It is actually as a result of that support that the group has been able to do so much good work over the past five years. However, the grant-in-aid program does not give an automatic re-grant right to organisations that have applied successfully in the past. This is because priorities are continually changing. It is important that other organisations providing for new immigrant communities are also catered for. In a competitive environment it is not surprising that some organisations, worthwhile as they may be, do not necessarily receive automatic funding because that is not a requirement of the program, a program which has been successful and able to attract State government funding. I am advised by the Department that if the Women in Industry: Contraception and Health organisation cares to make contact with the Department it may become eligible for a grant through another area of the Department's operations in the future. I would like to stress that grant-in-aid is not an automatic right. The organisation has received a great deal of support over the last five years. It is very much because of the work done in the past that it is now on a much firmer financial footing.

—Can the Minister for Resources inform the Senate whether the logging road currently being constructed through the National Estate forests on the east bank of the Picton River in Tasmania is being built with Federal Government approval? Is the Minister aware that part of that road will have to be built through either the area which was recently nominated for World Heritage listing or the Hartz Mountain National Park? Does the Minister realise that the east bank of the Picton River has been identified as having World Heritage qualities by the Australian Heritage Commission? Finally, how does the Minister reconcile the building of this road with the Prime Minister's promise of 12 June 1986 to protect National Estate values?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 January this year the Tasmanian Forestry Commission notified the Department of Primary Industries and Energy that it would be re-commencing-`re-commencing' being the operative word-the construction of 7.7 kilometres of roading in the east Picton area of the south-western Tasmanian National Estate area. The Commonwealth had been earlier advised of the roading in 1986 in accordance with clause 27 of the memorandum of understanding (MOU) which provides for the continuation of operations in National Estate forests in accordance with forest management plans previously approved by the Tasmanian Forestry Commission taking into account the Commonwealth's view. Six kilometres of roading was identified in the forest management plan for that part of the crown forest in the Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd concession in 1986 and in 1988. On 22 February 1989 the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, approved the re-commencement of the roading. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy has sought advice from the Australian Heritage Commission on what impact subsequent forestry operations will have on the National Estate values in the area.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth has not received any application from the Tasmanian Forestry Commission to extend the road further either through the area recently nominated for the World Heritage listing or through the Hartz Mountains National Park. But since Senator Sanders has directly implied in his question that this may well be its intention I will now ask the Tasmanian Forestry Commission what its intentions are with this road. If there are matters that I need to add to my answer, I will add to it in due course.

Agreement was reached between the Commonwealth and the Tasmanian governments on the areas to be nominated for World Heritage listing in November last year. Honourable senators may recall that Senator Richardson and I spent a lot of time hammering out that agreement. As I remember, something over 600,000 hectares of forests in Tasmania is now to be nominated for World Heritage listing as a consequence of that agreement. This brings to one hectare in seven in Tasmania that this Government has been responsible for, in one way or another, putting on the World Heritage List. The Commonwealth at that time made its judgment as to the area that it would nominate on the basis of a range of expert advices including, as honourable senators would know, the Helsham Lemonthyme and Southern Forests Commission of Inquiry. The area within which the roading is taking place to the east of the Picton is not nominated for World Heritage listing. Roading operations are being undertaken in accordance with the consultative mechanisms on logging and National Estate places in that MOU. The Australian Heritage Commission was and is being consulted on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs aware of doubts that have been raised concerning the legislative basis for the charging of a $240 administration fee for the review of immigration decisions by the immigration review panel process? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether there are any problems with the charging of this fee? If so, what action does he propose to take to deal with any such problems?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Merits review is not provided for in the Migration Act. In 1982, the then Minister for Immigration, Mr Macphee, introduced voluntary concessionary administrative review-the immigration review panel. In 1987, consistent with the Government's administrative responsibility and fiscal restraint, a service fee of $240 was introduced for this concessionary administrative review. Honourable senators will know that I am very much committed to reforming this immigration review system. Honourable senators will also recall that, during the Senate debate on the Migration Amendment Bill 1987, a clause intended to provide legislative entitlement for the reconsideration of certain decisions and a mechanism for the collection of fees for this service were deleted from that Bill. It is my understanding that, in opposing the clause, the Opposition did not intend to make invalid the current administratively based appeal mechanism. It is also my understanding that the Opposition supported the continued collection of the administratively based fee for the review of decisions under the Migration Act. This course has had the support of eminent lawyers. At the same time, it has had its critics, including some in the Parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: Recently, my Department sought further legal advice which adds to doubts about continuing the fee in its current form. More importantly, the Attorney-General wrote to me in December last year indicating that the better view is that the fee should have legislative backing. Upon receiving the Attorney-General's advice I considered whether it would be more appropriate to wait for the enactment of the new legislation or take immediate action by way of regulation. A strong impetus for immediate action was prompted by a report from the Ombudsman which unequivocally suggests that the fee should have a legislative base.

In the light of the uncertainty created by differing legal views, I am disposed to do away with the current administratively based review of migration decisions and replace it with a concept of second application. Such a second application scheme would be based on the regulation making power contained in section 67 of the Migration Act 1958. The current immigration review panel could and will be retained to advise on the consideration of second applications made under this scheme. The review opportunities currently existing would, in the main, be able to be accommodated in the second application regime. I propose to set the level of fee pay- able in respect of a second application at $240. As an interim measure, the second application regime would provide legislative support for a fee in respect of an examination of a person's claims by an independent outside body which would then make recommendations to the relevant decision maker. The introduction in this session of legislation flowing from the Government's response to the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, CAAIP, will enable the Parliament to decide whether it wants to provide for review of decisions made under the Migration Act. With the benefit of hindsight and in the light of the totality of advice, I can see the argument that the better view is that charging the fee should be given a legislative base. However, continuing to collect the fee, in my view, has not been unreasonable.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and follows his failure to answer the quite simple question put to him by Senator Durack relating to the Government's view of the decision by the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) to do a deal with Rothwells Ltd to stop an investigation. I remind the Minister of the clear vested political interest of his Government and of the Labor Government of Western Australia in covering up this matter. I ask the Minister: When did he first become aware of the fact that the NCSC had entered into an arrangement giving an undertaking not to take or recommend the taking of any action against Rothwells with respect to events prior to 27 November 1987? When was that first a matter that was known to him? Can he find out when it was first known to the Attorney-General and when it was first known to the Attorney-General's Department? They are the three matters on which I would like an answer. He should be able to give me an answer to the first part today, unless his memory has again failed him. Was the Minister aware of the proceedings by Connell in the Victorian Supreme Court seeking again to stop the NCSC from investigating matters relating to Rothwells? If he was aware of that, what inquiry was made by him or by the Attorney-General, or by the Attorney-Generals Department as to the content of that matter and the facts, which clearly include admissions by the NCSC that such a deal was made and that, therefore, there was a cover-up of these matters post-November 1987.

—As to the first question regarding when I was first aware of these matters, I will check whether I have any file note or anything which might enable me to give a precise answer. As to whether the Attorney or the Department has any file note which would indicate when or if they became aware of this, I will ask for information from them. As to the question of Connell trying to frustrate the investigation by the NCSC, of course I was aware of that, as was everyone, from media reports and other information that was flowing around the community. Of course I was aware of all that. The fact is that the matters which were at issue between Connell and the NCSC are a matter of public knowledge. There was no need to make any special effort to divine what was the subject of that particular court proceeding.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President, arising from that answer. Is the Minister saying that the first he knew of any deal to discontinue investigation in November 1987 was when he read about it in the media, following the Victorian Supreme Court proceedings commenced by Connell?
—I did not say that.

—I am asking for clarification. What action did the Minister or the Attorney or anyone in the Government take to inquire into that matter and to find out why such an extraordinary arrangement had been made?

—I have tried to make it extremely clear-I know it does not suit the political agenda of the Opposition-that the National Companies and Securities Commission is in a very peculiar situation as far as ministerial responsibility is concerned. The ministerial responsibility is to the Ministerial Council, which is comprised of the Attorneys of all Australian jurisdictions. The particular part which any Attorney plays in the deliberations and the supervision of the NCSC is, as I say, collective; it is part of a general supervisory control mechanism. If this Parliament, on the basis of a Senate committee report, agrees that that ought to be changed and that there ought to be more direct minis- terial responsibility to, for example, the Commonwealth Attorney-General, I hope it will support our proposals for changes in the companies and securities area.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, relates to the recent release of water from the Ranger mine in the Northern Territory. What are the results of tests which the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS) has been conducting on this released water? Further, is the Minister happy with the current regulatory arrangements for the control of operations at the Ranger mine?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of some recent actions at the Ranger mine which have led me to question the adequacy of current environment protection arrangements. For example, late last year as much as 500,000 tonnes of mineralised material containing uranium ore above the prescribed limit were wrongly placed on the waste rock dump site outside the mine's restricted release zone. The Northern Territory Government described this as trivial. I am still waiting for further information from the company, which it has twice promised and still not delivered, on that mistake. The final report from the Office of the Supervising Scientist will be available shortly. I await the report before deciding just how trivial the consequences of that incident might be. What it did demonstrate was that the company had been ignoring established and agreed procedures for perhaps up to six months.

ANSWER.PARA: Two weeks ago the mine operators released water over a three-day period from retention pond 4 (RP4), which is outside the restricted release zone. I might point out that the Office of the Supervising Scientist and the Aboriginal owners of the land were given only a few hours notice of that release. Preliminary laboratory biological tests by the OSS indicate that there have been some toxic effects. I expect more definitive advice from the Office within the next week or so. The release of this water into the Djalkmara Billabong-and eventually that means into the Magela Creek-was timed to coincide with wet season high water flows. It was authorised by the relevant Northern Territory authorities, but advice from the Office of the Supervising Scientist on the best method of release was ignored.

There are two principal methods of water release from retention pond 4-either via a spillway or via a pipeline. The Supervising Scientist has consistently advised the company and the Northern Territory authorities that the spillway is not acceptable because it allows less control of dilution and is more difficult to test for toxicity. Over the three years 1984 to 1987 all parties accepted this advice and water release from RP4 was, therefore, always via the pipeline. It is disturbing, strange, and remains unexplained why both the company and the Northern Territory authorities have suddenly decided to depart from this established procedure. I understand that my colleague Mr Kerin is also concerned about this and has written to both the Northern Territory Government and the company concerned complaining about these occurrences. I am also concerned that the company is planning further releases from retention pond 4 via the spillway.

These recent actions by the Ranger mine, which have been far too readily accepted by the Northern Territory authorities, suggest that the Commonwealth's advice on environmental protection for the Ranger mine is not being given sufficient weight. The Supervising Scientist has advised me that if this process continues the high standards of environmental protection in the Alligator Rivers Region will be threatened. Accordingly, I have asked for a number of options to be examined that might enable the Commonwealth properly to fulfil its obligations in this regard. These options include the possibility of using legal powers under the Atomic Energy Act, which is administered by Mr Kerin, under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, or the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act.

Obviously, as all honourable senators will be aware, the Kakadu National Park and the World Heritage area in the Northern Territory are of unparalleled international significance, let alone domestic significance. The Commonwealth will take whatever action is necessary to prevent that heritage from being threatened. The wetlands of Kakadu will not be allowed to become a drain, to be used at the convenience of either the company or the Northern Territory Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Did the Minister note in the Australian Institute of Family Studies report, Families and Tax in 1989, released yesterday, that real disposable income for most families has fallen sharply under the Hawke Government? Did she note in particular the decline in real values of family concessions, namely, the family allowance, the dependent spouse rebate, and the sole parent rebate? Does she appreciate the economic stress suffered by families under the Hawke Government's policies and the extent to which it is being borne by women? What is she going to do about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not read the article to which Senator Hill refers.
—It is a report.

—I have not read the report to which Senator Hill refers. I look forward to reading it. The Government's record in relation to providing for Australian families is well known. The Government's work in relation to improving living standards, particularly in relation to the creation of a large number of jobs, over a million, is way in excess of the response of the Fraser-Howard Government in its seven years of office. The Opposition continually tries to put forward the notion that the Government has done nothing for families when over and over again the Government's long commitment to Australian families has been documented. I can cite the work that has been done in relation to health. I invite honourable senators to look at the Opposition's policies in that respect. There were eight different health care programs under the Howard Government.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The Minister's answer is wholly irrelevant to the question that was asked, which related squarely to the fact that specific concessions for families with dependants during the term of this Government have significantly lost value. The Minister, as is becoming increasingly common in this place, is waffling on about something entirely different. Her answer is utterly irrelevant. She is not able to answer the question which relates to the dreadful situation with respect to these concessions. I ask you to call her to order. If she does not know the answer, she should simply say so and sit down.
—Order! I was listening to the Minister's answer and I thought she was talking about health costs for families and, as such, was relevant.

—I rise on a point of order again, Mr President. The question very clearly related to a major report which has had extensive publicity around Australia today. As I recall the question asked by my colleague Senator Hill, it related specifically to the question of taxation and other concessions relating to families and had nothing to do with health and other services. In the interests of our having some rational question time, I ask you to keep the Minister to some rule of relevance.

—I also rise on a point of order, Mr President. Historically, Presidents in this place, as Senator Chaney well knows, have been unable to direct Ministers as to how they answer questions. Senator Chaney is asking you to introduce a new rule into this place. If that is the case, he should take it to the Senate Standing Committee on Procedure to get an answer.
—Order! I have no power to direct a Minister how to answer a question. I will listen to the answer to see whether the Minister is debating the question. I call Senator Reynolds.

—I have in front of me an answer that has been provided, which essentially keeps along the lines in which I was moving. I was talking about the employment growth created by this Government over the last six years. I was talking about the advantages to families from the introduction of Medicare. I can go on to detail some more advantages, if the Opposition would like to hear them.

ANSWER.PARA: We have taken specific measures to assist low income families so that the burden of economic restraint would be borne fairly. Our concern is with fairness and equity. It is important to remember what Future Directions says in relation to equity. For example, it states:

. . . Labor policies . . . have attempted to shield certain groups in the community from the effects of a reduced national income . . . Unless these policies are reversed, the current account deficit . . . will continue to grow.

Senator Hill spoke about the living standards of families, yet the Liberal Party document sets out quite clearly the intention of the Opposition in relation to families, particularly those families most in need.

I conclude by running through a few other initiatives. We have provided for an increase in rent assistance for low income families. By June 1990, families with three or more children will have had their rent assistance doubled and families with one or two children will have had their rent assistance increased by two-thirds. Medicare has saved families at least $21 per week in private insurance costs. We have increased education allowances. For example, we have more than doubled the rate for 16- to 17-year-old secondary students. We have also increased the retention rates, particularly for girls. We have boosted the year 12 retention rate to 57.6 per cent, compared to about 36 per cent in 1982. I have already talked about the dramatic increase in the number of child care places.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. As I understand the Minister's answer, she is misleading the Senate because she is saying something quite contradictory to that which she told the Senate yesterday. She told the Senate yesterday that she did not want to say anything about economic policy because it would tip off the conference about what she thought. Now she is prepared to give an answer. Therefore she has been misleading yesterday or today.
—There is no point of order. Has Senator Reynolds finished her answer?
—I have adequately answered the question and I do not wish to take up any more time of the Senate.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HOCKEY: GRANTS BY AUSTRALIAN SPORTS COMMISSION

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I noticed in a recent report of the Australian Sports Commission that approximately twice as many women as men are registered as hockey players, yet men's hockey receives approximately twice as much funding from the Australian Sports Commission.
—Who wins?

—I acknowledge the honourable senator's interjection. Can the Minister say whether this is still the case and, if not, how has it changed and what are the criteria by which the Australian Sports Commission allocates funds to sports under its funding program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The sports development program of the Australian Sports Commission provides assistance to national associations for such things as the appointment of an administrator or a national coach, or the staging of international events. On occasions, it also provides funds for travel overseas to international competitions. When deciding funding levels, the Commission takes into account proposals submitted to it by the national sporting organisations concerned. Hence, funding decisions are a reflection of the requests that have been received.

ANSWER.PARA: The grants to men's and women's hockey under the 1987-88 program were $146,000 and $82,000 respectively. The difference is a reflection of the fact that men's hockey requested greater funding for travel assistance and also requested funds for a junior development officer. The junior development officer, by the way, was of direct benefit to both boys and girls hockey. It is important also to point out that the sports development program is only part of the Government's total assistance to sport. For example, under the 1987-88 sports talent encouragement plan, STEP as it is known, both men's and women's hockey received $64,000. This year, however, men's hockey received $64,000, but women's hockey received $80,000. The overall level of Government assistance to hockey in general in 1988-89 is $867,000. In addition to this, the Federal Government has contributed $200,000 towards the resurfacing of the Perth Hockey Stadium. I hope that adequately answers the question. There has been no discrimination against women's hockey. In any event, this year women's hockey is getting more than men's hockey.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the widely leaked and apparently genuine letter from the Deputy Secretary to his Department, Mr Duncan Campbell, to the Minister's predecessor, Mr Bill Hayden. The letter reveals that the extremely high level KGB agent, Valery Zemskov, was given a visa to enter Australian in order to pose here as a diplomat before the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) had time to complete a security check on him. I note in this connection Mr Campbell's statement: `We can safely assume, I believe, that a number of senior Soviet diplomats have some sort of intelligence role'.
