If so, was the Prime Minister made aware of the Minister's decision at the time or was he in any other way involved in it? If the then Minister was not personally involved in the decision to issue this visa to this extremely high level KGB officer, at what level in his Department was that decision taken? What, if any, disciplinary measures have been taken against the officer responsible? Does the Minister agree with Mr Campbell's view that `we can safely assume that a number of senior Soviet diplomats have some sort of intelligence role'? If so, does he share what appears to be the sense of complacency on that score being expressed by a Deputy Secretary to his Department?

—I am sorry to have to disappoint Senator Stone in the construction of his new conspiracy theory but, in accordance with longstanding practice, the Government will not comment on press reports about intelligence and security matters. I do not propose to breach that practice on this occasion.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Notwithstanding the aridity of the Minister's response, I remind him that in this chamber on 4 November last year I referred to the position of Mr Zemskov in this country and to the public revelation-it had been known to the Australian Government for almost three years at that time-of Mr Zemskov's extremely high level ranking as a KGB officer. I ask again: does the Minister really believe that this shutting down of the cover up that he is now attempting to impose will dispose of this matter?
—I congratulate Senator Stone on his prescience demonstrated on 4 November, but I still have nothing to add to my previous answer.

—Is the Minister for Resources aware of the recent deaths of 178 animals being transported on an aircraft travelling from Sydney to Adelaide? If so, is he aware of the circumstances and what action does he propose to take to prevent a recurrence of this incident?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of what I regard to be a tragic and avoidable incident which occurred recently when 178 goats were being transferred or shipped from Sydney via Adelaide to Singapore aboard a British Airways aircraft.
—You were having a Labor conference in Singapore, were you?

—This may be a matter of some levity on the Opposition side. In terms of animal welfare, I happen to regard this matter as serious and as deserving of some dignity in terms of my reply in the Senate. I am also aware that last December some 40 deer died on a flight between New Zealand and Melbourne. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, the service that has concern for the welfare of animals and plant life in and out of Australia, has investigated both incidents. Its responsibility in terms of these matters is to ensure that the loading and transport arrangements are such as not to adversely affect the welfare or health of animals being transported, but the responsibility for animal welfare during flight or carriage lies with the agency or the carrier in the particular circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: In the case of the goats, I can report to the Senate that I am advised that they were inspected by quarantine staff at approximately midday on the date of travel and were certified fit to travel. The veterinary officer concerned was satisfied that the loading densities in the transport crates were satisfactory and complied with International Air Transport Association standards. The goats were loaded into the aircraft hold 30 minutes prior to the expected time of departure. The carrier, British Airways, has reported that thereafter a series of problems with the aircraft, its fuel load and some minor repairs delayed take-off by between one and two hours. This in turn required a change of crew and further delay then occurred.

As a result of those delays and because of human error nothing was done to open the hold, the goats remained enclosed and because of the delay were asphyxiated. In those circumstances I regard it as a tragic and avoidable event. As I have said, the responsibility of this part of travel is that of the airline and something that airlines have to pay attention to. If humans were involved in a delay of this nature they would be attended to. Transport carriers are required to see that live cargoes are attended to and receive similar consideration in those circumstances.

With respect to the consignment of deer which were delivered dead by asphyxiation on arrival in Melbourne, they had been inspected and passed fit to travel by New Zealand veterinary officers. In that incident incorrect data on load densities had been fed into a controlling computer and as a result insufficient air was circulated through the hold during the flight. As a result of these two incidents I have taken a personal interest in this matter. Quarantine officers have met with the officials of the airlines concerned. I am advised that the Chief Quarantine Officers (Animals) in both New South Wales and Victoria have reported to the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service that they are satisfied now that the efforts of the airlines will be such to ensure that no incidents of this nature recur. However, we are taking the matter up further with the airlines involved-all airlines who may be involved with carriage of this nature-to ensure that the carriage of livestock into and out of Australia is handled in a way conducive to animal welfare practice and proper human practice and that handling, loading and loading practices and transport of animals are observed in the way in which the regulations, both national and international, require them to be.

—Has the Minister for Consumer Affairs seen a report in today's Sydney Morning Herald titled `Curbs to be eased on loan sharks'? Does the report indicate an intention on behalf of the New South Wales Government to replace its existing credit legislation with a system of industry self-regulation? Would such an approach undermine the achievements of uniform credit legislation across all States and Territories?
—It looked after Rothwells so well.
—If so, what would be its impact on consumers, the finance industry and the agreement reached by State and Federal consumer affairs Ministers in 1988?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answering Senator Childs's question-I will ignore the pathetic little rantings from Senator Chaney in this particular part of the proceedings-I should say by way of background, that it has been the long term aim of governments in this country for almost 15 years to obtain uniform credit legislation across the States and Territories. In July 1988 a big step forward was taken when State and Federal Ministers agreed, first, to achieve uniformity and, secondly, to proceed with drafting legislation to achieve this uniformity. The keenness to obtain uniformity has been shown on the part of Government, on the part of industry, which has been very keen to obtain a level playing field in this area, and on the part of consumer groups. Consumer groups can see the benefits of facilitating consumer awareness because of uniform legislation covering all legislatures in Australia. The step forward taken in July 1988 has been proceeded with. The Victorian Law Reform Commission, under the auspices of the Standing Committee of Consumer Affairs Ministers (SCOCAM) officials has been drafting legislation for some time. We anticipate that that draft legislation will be available for consideration by Ministers when they meet again in July this year.

ANSWER.PARA: At this stage I should also say that industry cooperation, in terms of obtaining that agreement amongst Ministers, was extremely vital. That was recognised at the time. The New South Wales Minister, Mr Peacocke, who was part of the agreement said two things which I believe are worth placing on the record. He said:
I want to make our position quite clear . . . We have not taken a position where we in any way wish to deviate from a uniform approach to credit legislation. I want to make that quite clear.
In response to the Victorian Minister, he said:
May I say that I would like to congratulate you and the Law Reform Commission on an excellent piece of work. It is outstanding.

Of course, the work which he was referring to was the early drafts of the uniform consumer credit legislation. It is interesting to note a number of things in the press report of this morning. The aim of consumer Ministers was, of course, to obtain adequate consumer protection as well as to obtain uniformity. At the outset, I should say that I am pleased that both the report and the proposal, to the extent that that proposal is clear and definite, express a commitment to the agreement made in July last year at SCOCAM and a commitment to retain all existing consumer protection. There are however, some parts of the report, and of the document detailing the proposal, that place the intentions of the New South Wales Government very much on trial, giving very strong warning signals to both consumer groups and industry in respect of whether those aims which were set out are achievable.

For consumers, I think the basic point is that there needs to be effective, cheap access to redress mechanisms. That point is not spelled out so far in the proposal. There needs to be an effective screening of lenders. The SCOCAM meeting allowed individual States to agree on whether they should adopt positive or negative licensing. However, underlying the intention of all Ministers was the effective mechanism of screening lenders. To that extent there are doubts over the New South Wales proposal. Also, in terms of consumer interest, there needs to be very much a strong focus retained on the priority area of consumer credit for individual consumers. We want to ensure that they are not swamped by the introduction of other areas of credit.

In relation to industry, industry at the time was concerned, as it would be concerned now, that the proposal may give deregulation a bad name. The document I have seen proposes a parallel system of both regulation and self-regulation. Parallel mechanisms to protect consumers could, in this instance, lead to a cumbersome, confusing, and even costly situation. Industry expressed concern last year at that degree of inconsistency and I suspect that it will still be concerned with that inconsistency now.

As it stands, therefore, the proposal which I have seen is very much a step into the unknown. I do acknowledge the commitments made by Mr Peacocke last year and which have been repeated this year. If those benchmarks which were made at SCOCAM-that is, adequate consumer protection and uniformity-are to be achieved, there is an obligation on all the players in the field, whether they be industry groups, consumer groups or others, not to react emotively to the Peacocke proposal. The obligation is to continue to make a constructive input in the area, just as the input was made last year by State and Federal Ministers, and accordingly to achieve those goals which we set one year ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to change its policies which are depriving increasing numbers of young Australians of the opportunity to own their own homes.

I bring this matter of urgency before the Senate today because of its overriding priority to millions of Australians. Home ownership has dwindled to the point where it now has the status of being a privilege. In the past it used to be the right of all Australians to have their own home. This state of affairs has occurred because the Labor Government has been in office for six years. Mr Keating has told the Australian public-I presume that he was speaking on behalf of Senator Richardson and the rest of the Government-that Australians have to lower their expectations. They cannot afford to have a clothes hoist or a swimming pool. That may be the expectations that the Australian Labor Party wants to inflict on the public of Australia, but let me say unequivocally, speaking on behalf of my colleagues, that we do not want to see those standards inflicted on young Australians when we take office.

We have heard the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) express his concern about the economy, and rightly so. Let us look at some of the macro-economic disasters that are having an effect on high interest rates. The result is that a number of young Australians are not able to afford their own homes. In March 1983 home loan interest rates were 12.5 per cent; in February 1989 they were 15.5 per cent. Bankruptcies have risen from the Fraser average of 4,717 to 9,421 in 1987-88. Our current account deficit has increased from an average of $4.7 billion to $11.7 billion under Keating who wants us to dry our clothes in a clothes drier and refuses to give the young people of Australia a clothes line. Foreign debt has escalated from $35.5 billion and 20.9 per cent of gross domestic product in June 1983 to $121 billion and 40.2 per cent of GDP in September. The marginal tax rate for the average income earner was 30c in the dollar in 1983; it is now 40c in every dollar. Home loan repayments have increased from an average monthly repayment of $350, or 19.2 per cent of income in March 1983, to an astounding $778 or nearly 31 per cent of income in September 1988. If members of the Labor Party do not think that there is a housing crisis in Australia that is affecting our young families, then they must be the only ones in Australia who are not aware of the problem.

I will just go through some of the headlines in today's capital city papers: In the Courier-Mail the headline is `City home crisis hits thousands, says report'. The article states that 17 people are sharing a two-bedroom house. `Mortgages up-$27 extra on average home loan', said the Daily Telegraph. `Up they go', says the Melbourne Sun; `Sydney families $30 a week worse off', is the headline in the Daily Mirror; `High home loans here to stay: PM', which admits defeat; and `House prices to jump by $32,000', are headlines in the Daily Telegraph. We are told that we have nothing to worry about, but these headlines indicate the effect on everyone in Australia as this Labor Party clears the decks in its final run-up to an election later this year before the whole economy collapses around it like a pack of cards. The Prime Minister will have to race to get to an election before the economy crashes. It will almost be a dead heat. The average household is paying an extra $49 a week.

Qualifying income to buy an average priced first home has doubled since early 1985 from $23,000 to $46,000. We can go on and on about those figures, but we are not receiving any response from the Government. Sixty thousand people now live on the verge of homelessness and 40,000 sleep in the open or in refuges. They are refugees from this Labor Government who seek shelter just as the refugees from Afghanistan had to seek shelter. Not I nor the papers or press or the people of Australia seem to be able to rouse any response from the Labor Government. The Government thinks that it can solve a crisis of massive proportions by holding a summit. I am not against the summit. I am not against anything that can give some type of relief to Australia's homeless people. But I think the summit needs to be put down for what it is: a desperate bid by the Prime Minister to be seen to be doing something. The Australian people have sacrificed too much. In terms of quality of life, the sacrifice has been excessive.

The Government is taking $82.3 billion from Australians in this tax year. The loss to the taxpayer in real disposable income ranges from $41 to $72 a week, depending on whether a person is a single taxpayer or a member of a two-income family with two children. The company tax was reduced by this Government two years ago. I do not argue with that, but the workers of Australia are still waiting for their tax cuts. They have been put off for two years. Even now, on the eve of some tax cuts, no-one is sure what the figure will be.

There is great uncertainty amongst Government Ministers, one saying one thing, one saying another. Some Ministers say, `We cannot afford to give tax cuts', but the Prime Minister is determined to go ahead. I will be interested to see-and I will be waiting with bated breath-what those tax cuts are.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not hold my breath.

—I would not hold my breath. I would not like to be a worker hoping for something to increase my standard of living. It is a shocking indictment of this Labor Government when 2.6 million people in Australia live below the poverty line. Twenty per cent of those people are children.

SPEECH.PARA: Second only to the Government's fondness for summits is its addiction to taxes. We have never before seen such a plethora of taxes come before a nation as in the six years of this Government's reign. Fringe benefit tax, capital gains tax, entertainment tax, company tax, wholesale taxes, petrol excise increases, wine taxes, superannuation fund income taxes, gold taxes, graduate taxes: the taxes go on and on. I wonder what else the Treasurer (Mr Keating) can tax when he brings down his report in April. Surely he must have reached the limit.

TALK.START.PARA: —He will find something.
—The honourable senator says he has got to find something.
—He will not tax his rich mates.
—I cannot believe there is anything left in Australia that has not been taxed. If it moves, it is taxed; if it stays still, it is taxed.
—If it is dead, tax it.

—If it is dead, it is taxed. We just cannot keep on taxing the Australian population. It is having a very degrading effect on young people who are seeking homes. I hope that we do not have to lower our expectations in this country. There is no need for us to do that. For a senior Minister of this Government to say that we have to lower our expectations is the greatest example of defeatism I have ever heard. Why do we have to lower our expectations? There is an alternative to lowering our expectations: vote for the coalition and people will return to the prosperity that they enjoyed over a number of years.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been said that I do not support the summit. I do support it because I think it is bringing people together. It will create debate and awareness, and it may do some- thing marginal to lift the awareness of the Government, although Government members should not be unaware of the problems if they read the newspapers every day. Some of the States have done quite a lot for young home buyers and new home buyers. The Queensland Government has lifted the stamp duty for first home buyers on houses costing up to $80,000. I am sure that measure has been well received and I recommend it to the other States. The maximum Housing Commission loan has been raised to $75,000. Some 122,000 hectares of land previously set aside for railway purposes has now been freed for housing and parkland development.

Whilst those sorts of things relieve some of the pressure, they are only going round the sides of the issue. The main issue that confronts this Government is its poor economic performance over the last six years. The people who are bearing the brunt of that economic performance are the young home buyers of Australia. No wonder Australia's population growth is down to zero. This has been caused by the housing crisis in Australia as more and more people have to have two incomes. The wife has to go out to work, and the stage at which couples can have children is getting later. The only way families are able to own their own homes is for women to remain in the work force longer. This is affecting the Australian way, Australian families, and the birth rate in this country.

The Queensland Government has set up a crisis hot line which is taking over 500 calls a week from distressed families and individuals. There has been a marked increase in phone calls from people seeking help. Mortgage payments have risen because this Labor Government has used interest rates as an economic policy tool. It is not affecting the big people; they can live through it. But it is affecting Labor Party supporters, or people who were Labor Party supporters. No government could have hit the family harder than Labor has. There are pressures on family incomes through excessive home loan repayments. The need for two incomes to sustain the high level mortgage repayments needed to meet today's housing crisis puts great pressure on family life.

The main problems facing first home buyers are tied into the state of the national economy: affordability, the increasing cost of land, interest rates, the deposit gap and inadequate savings. As Senator Stone has informed me, housing cannot be isolated from the rest of the economy. Senator Stone has told me, and he is quite correct, that anything else we do will be a stopgap measure. Unless we can get the economy under control, get interest rates down and set macro-economic policies on a course for development, we will only be going round the edges. From the mid-1970s this Government has seen a levelling off of real income, an increased number of welfare dependants and interest rates escalating to historically high levels. The hardest hit in the current crisis have been the least able to pay the price-the young single income families wanting to buy a home and those on low incomes consigned to the private sector. That is the reason that I raise this matter of public importance today.

I shall be interested to hear what the Government has to say about this crisis that is affecting most young married families. I shall be listening to what Senator Cook puts down. I hope that he is not just busily scribbling notes down now on the run. I hope he has put some thought into this. I hope he has gone to see the Treasurer and the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples). I hope he is going to present to the Senate a plan that will give some hope to the people who are struggling under the burden of high interest rates inflicted by this callous Labor Government.

The Commonwealth Bank of Australia-Housing Industry Association index for all capital cities over the last 12 months to December 1988 showed that the median price for an existing home has risen by 44.6 per cent, from $77,000 to nearly $112,000. At the same time average household disposable income rose by 4.9 per cent from $32,500 to $34,000 while the affordability index declined from 132.7 to 99.0. That is why young families in Australia are having to live with their parents, which creates tremendous pressure, to live in flats under their parents' homes, live in caravans or, if they are fortunate enough to be able to afford it, in a unit or a flat. But it is stopping them from achieving the dream of owning their own house.

When Labor came to power in 1983 the average home took 19 per cent of disposable income of the Australian home buyer. The situation now is that the average home loan grabs a massive 30 per cent of household income, and that percentage is continuing to rise. In 1988 the average home loan cost $733 a month. It is going to increase by the end of this year to $1,000 a month. That is the legacy that this Government has inflicted on the Australian people over the last six years. It has been economically irresponsible. The Government is not paying the price. It is not big business that is paying the price. It is the average Australian family that the Government has neglected. The Government has walked away from its base, its political grass roots, its heartland, and has left those people to suffer. It has let interest rates escalate, and the people have had their housing reduced. The standard of housing is shocking. People are now reduced to living in a little eight-square brick box when the average standard of a working man's dwelling eight to 10 years ago was a nice 13-square home. So not only are people not able to afford a decent standard of home, but when they do get into a home the standard has well and truly been reduced due to the Labor Party's shocking handling of the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keating has got three homes and can't remember which one he lives in, for his travelling allowance.
—Keating may have three homes. I do not mind if Keating has 33 homes. What I object to--
—Order! Senator Boswell, the President has recently drawn attention to the fact that you must refer to Mr Keating as the Treasurer.

—The Treasurer can have as many homes as he wants, and I do not object to that. What I object to is when the Treasurer says that everyone else has got to reduce his expectations. That is a shocking admission of defeat and one that this coalition will never entertain. We believe that this country can offer everyone a decent home if it is managed correctly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not considering, as Senator Boswell said, a matter of public importance: it is an urgency motion. Senator Boswell has put before the Senate an urgency motion which is nothing short of being a straight-out, transparent, political stunt. It was a political stunt that was tried in the House of Representatives yesterday--
—How about the housing summit?

—I am worried about Senator Stone's health; he should not get so excited. This was tried in the House of Representatives by the Opposition's housing spokesman, Alexander Downer. He raised a matter of public importance: perhaps that is why Senator Boswell is confused. The words are almost the same and the intent of bringing this matter before the Senate is the same as that of Downer yesterday.
—Order! The same ruling applies to Mr Downer.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I will observe the courtesies. The same intent as Mr Downer had in raising the matter of public importance applies to this urgency motion. It is nothing short of a petty, tawdry and, above all else, carping and transparent attempt to deflect public attention from what is going on in the Cabinet room as we speak-a national summit on housing, a national summit which has been created, driven, and I believe will be acted on by this Government to address problems in housing supply.

SPEECH.PARA: In his opening remarks Senator Boswell made two interesting comments which should be focused on for a second, but no longer than a second, because that would waste time. Firstly, he said that if members of the Australian Labor Party do not think there is a housing crisis they are the only ones in Australia who do not think so. Secondly, he said that the Opposition did not seem to be able to rouse any response from Labor on this issue. Labor thinks that there is a problem and it is doing something about it. We are not carping; we are not being petty; and we are not trying to turn this issue into a political football. We are being constructive and proactive. We are trying to reach a solution to meet what is not an interest rate problem but a supply problem in terms of the availability of land for housing.

As we speak, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) are meeting the Premiers at a special out of session Premiers Conference for the purposes of looking at how we can put more land on the market so that there will be more availability, land prices will be brought down, and people will have more access to building blocks, and so that we can look at any obstructions there might be in the labour market to make sure that there is a supply of skilled labour to meet any further demands on what is already an overheated housing construction section. We are also looking at building materials supply so that any blockages in the supply of building materials can be overcome. We are talking to the Premiers about zoning problems and are looking at how servicing of blocks can be made more efficient so that those blocks can become available and so that the market, which is overheating, will be met-not in the way it would have been met in the bad old days of the Fraser Government, that is, by damping down, blocking and stopping it and throwing the economy back into recession, which Senator Stone knows all about, thus killing demand and putting people out of housing, but by looking constructively at what needs to be done to overcome the blockage. That is the distinct difference between our two parties and one of the reasons that just a few weeks ago a Labor government won a State election in this country.

We are not going to the Premiers just on the basis that the Commonwealth is not doing anything. We have already announced, as a prelude to the summit, a release on the market of 27,000 building blocks over the next five years, which is equivalent to the creation of 15 new suburbs. Commonwealth land which we can make available for housing construction will be progressively released over time in order to take some of the heat off the shortage of land supply. Obviously we are not going to release it all at once and create a major bottleneck. We are going to release it over time. It will be a phased-in meeting of the problem.

I expect real change and improvement as a result of the initiative of the Hawke Government being conducted today in this building. There is a problem, and it is the proper course for government to recognise when there is a problem and to say so honestly. It is also the proper obligation of government then to address the problem, which we are doing. The mechanisms to answer the problem are available to us and we are putting them in place. To take a cynical view, there are likely to be three State elections this year: in Tasmania, Queensland and South Australia. So there is real electoral impetus on two conservative governments and one Labor government to make sure that the supply side problem is met in political terms. That is why I think this initiative of the Hawke Government will be successful. The Opposition's tawdry, pathetic and transparent attempt to deflect attention from it will not work. It did not work for Mr Downer yesterday; it will not work for Senator Boswell today. Most of the news tonight will not be about what Senator Boswell said in this debate; it will be about the positive outcome of our initiative because Australian people want to see a positive outcome.

Having dealt with that, let me go to some analysis of the problem-something that Senator Boswell refused to undertake. He talked vaguely and generally about interest rates, he waffled about tax and then he beat his breast about the Queensland Government. That does not frighten us in terms of an urgency motion. All of those things can be dealt with properly. All of those things, in the way in which the honourable senator put them, are beside the point in this debate. They are not at the core of the issue. The problem is that we need to improve the supply of building blocks in Australia and get them on to the market. We need to overcome problems in zoning and servicing which prevent those blocks being taken up. We need to recognise the difficulties in the labour market and in building materials supply. The affordability problem, which has gained a lot of focus and attention in this debate, seriously afflicts Sydney more than all the other capital cities, though it also affects Melbourne to some extent. But elsewhere there is not the same problem. If one looks at the national affordability statistics one will see that the problem is most chronic in Sydney and slightly less so in Melbourne. The national affordability average is much lower than the average for those cities.

What we recognise as a government, with a hands on responsibility and an orderly way of dealing with these problems-not driven by hysteria but by rational analysis-is that Australians seek by choice to live in three different types of housing environment. The first choice, often referred to as the Australian dream, is to own one's own home. Not all Australians seek to do so, but most do. We want to set our policies to encourage those who aspire to that dream to achieve it. We also recognise that some people seek rental in public housing and in private housing. That is a choice that they make. Not in all cases is that choice an easy one, and sometimes the cost of moving into owner-occupied housing delays the transition. But if that is their choice, the obligation of a government with responsibility for housing in a democracy is to make available the realisation of the choice individuals want to make. So we recognise those three choices. I repeat, however, that the burden of our policy settings is to enable Australians to move into home ownership.

We have in place a series of mechanisms-we do not need the summit for this-to ensure that that Australian aspiration, in whatever form it takes, is met. The first and most important mechanism that we, as a government, have put in place to rectify this situation is the first home owners scheme. Since we introduced the scheme in 1983, and swept aside the ill targeted, ill conceived tax measures that the previous Fraser Government had in place, which, during the Fraser Government-led recession, were proved not to have worked very effectively at all, we have injected $1.4 billion into home purchasing and the paying off of home loans for low income Australians. That has enabled 318,000 households to benefit directly from that scheme. We recognise the difficulties of overheating. Nonetheless, we have focused on making it possible for low income Australians to achieve the outcome in home ownership that they desire. We have been outstandingly successful in that and we will persist with it.

The second important alteration we have made to the landscape of home ownership is the deregulation of the financial market. I would be interested to hear what Senator Stone has to say on this later; he is writing something at the moment and if his scribblings in newspapers and his speeches in this place are any indication, I think he would have wanted the Fraser Government to deregulate, but it lacked the will to do so. When the Fraser Government had control of the levers of the economy and sought to do things, what did it do? When money was tight, the banks could limit the amount of money on loan by keeping interest rates low. Therefore there was not sufficient money available in the pool for home loans. That is how the Fraser Government did it. By deregulating the market we have guaranteed that housing finance will not dry up and that money is available. Under the Fraser Government it dried up and it was not available.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rates of interest?

—Let me cover this interesting point. The honourable senator asks, `What rates of interest?'. There are now record take-ups in home loan borrowings in Australia. By deregulating the finance market-something Senator Stone was never able to persuade the Fraser Government to do-we have pumped more money into the market than ever before. That is the key reason why we are facing an overheating of the market. More loans are being taken out. The supply of properly serviced blocks, labour and materials is causing the bottleneck in meeting the demand for home ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear interjections. They are a babble, but I assume they are a defence mechanism for the Opposition. Let us look at the statistics. We expect that this year there will be 164,000 home construction commencements. That is the expectation of the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry Association. What was the situation in 1982-83 when that lot opposite were in office? There were 105,000 commencements.
—What was the population then?

—The population has not varied greatly since then. If anything, the age structure of the population is beneficial to this analysis. If honourable senators want me to give further comparisons of figures, I shall. The rate of home starts per thousand head of population in the past five years has been 8.54 per cent, whereas under the Fraser Government it was 8.2 per cent, much lower.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition senators talk about interest rates. They should answer those statistics I have given on this occasion. As I have said, that is why there is an access problem and why there is overheating. Thus we have the housing summit and the efforts to alleviate and moderate that overheating. It is an indication of success in the economy, not of failure, that that has occurred. I do not, however, want to sit down in this debate before I have focused on one of the key elements which differentiates us from the Opposition. What is the difference between a solid, good, effective and delivering Labor Government and the ineffectual transparent and carping Opposition? The one thing that has traditionally differentiated us and which remains as a key differentiation is our concern about public housing, our concern about how battlers in Australia get into housing and our concern about providing a roof over their heads.

SPEECH.PARA: If one wants to look at what the Opposition did when it was in government compared to what we are doing now, one will see that the statistics belie any allegations or pretence that the Opposition may wish to make. Let me go in an orderly way, therefore, through the comparisons in terms of public housing. Commonwealth assistance for public housing has in real terms under this Government doubled from what the Opposition provided when in government.

If the Opposition wants to espouse itself as a champion of the poor and underprivileged, why did it provide only half the funds that we will provide for this section of the community, in real terms, in inflation adjusted terms? In public housing 250,000 households have been accommodated under us compared with 165,000 under the Opposition's five years of government. Home loans were provided to 70,000 low income households by us compared with 50,000 by the Opposition over a five-year comparative period. An additional 70,000 rental dwellings have been provided by us compared with 40,000 by the Opposition over a comparative five-year period.

Our record in almost every aspect of meeting demand and of providing housing for low income earners in this country is almost twice as effective as the Opposition's-in real terms, adjusted for inflation. The Opposition should not come in here pretending that somehow or other it will be trying to represent the voice of the people who are in low income circumstances. One has only to look back to how callous and non-compassionate the Opposition was in the period in which it was in office.

Let me go on with this comparison a little further. I know the Opposition will not wish me to because it is the key point which shows us in sharp contrast. This Government has also targeted assistance to low and middle income earners in the private rental market. Rental assistance has been increased to $15 a week and has been extended to those receiving the family allowance supplement and to parents on unemployment benefit. This is the first time that any Federal government has provided rent assistance to working families on low incomes. Further changes to rent assistance announced in the 1988 Budget will also help reduce the incidence of housing related poverty in the private rental sector. Rent assistance for pensioners, beneficiaries and family allowance supplement recipients will rise progressively to a maximum of $30 a week for large families by June 1990. By June 1990 pensioners and beneficiaries without children will have received a 100 per cent increase in the maximum rate of rent assistance since 1983 while those with children will have received an increase of between 150 per cent and 200 per cent.

Our concern about how the problems of housing in Australia impact upon the lower end of the income scale has, by the statistical test, by the real terms test, by the inflation adjusted test, proven to be twice as compassionate and as concerned as the Opposition's. This is not only the case in the public housing sector. We have delivered the goods in the private housing sector with rent supplements and assistance to people in real need.

That is not to say that we do not recognise the ongoing difficulties. But we have delivered the goods in a vastly superior way to anything that the Opposition has considered. Let us not have this political posturing, this petty transparent carping and the sort of slander that Senator Boswell has come out with. Why not concentrate on using this chamber to promote a positive debate in the summit, wait until we see the outcome of it and wait until we see what the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the State Premiers have been able to put forward? If, then, the Opposition has some criticisms, let us hear them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin with a pun: a pox on both your houses. I listened to Senator Cook attempt to illustrate the difference between the Government and the Opposition. While the Government is entirely to blame for the problem in the housing sector, had the Opposition been in government the situation would be precisely the same. Essentially, there are no differences between the policies that the two major parties have pursued and will be pursuing.
—The problem is that you are incapable of distinguishing between them.

—I say to Senator Stone that that indicates that the differences are very subtle. Certainly, they would be lost on people in this country who are in dire straits with respect to housing. One might support this matter of urgency merely on the grounds that had the Opposition been in government, I am quite sure it would not have dared to go as far down the road of deregulation as the Government has or implemented the other policies-which I will deal with in a moment-that the Government has implemented. The situation might well have been better had the Opposition been in government or had this Government stuck closer to its traditional policies and supported ordinary people. It has not done that.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation is very serious. The figures speak for themselves, despite what Senator Cook has said. Median house prices in the State capitals and in Canberra rose by an average of $9,200 during the September quarter last year. During the same period, average household disposable income dropped by $200. By the mid-quarter last year, bank mortgage rates had risen to 14.5 per cent. As we know, they have now risen further. In the last quarter of last year, a person who wanted to borrow money to buy a house costing the national median price of $103,000 needed to earn $46,000 per year to meet the Commonwealth Bank's loan criteria, assuming a 25 per cent deposit. If one takes out the figure for inflation, this amount is double the $23,000 a buyer needed in 1985, only three years ago and two years into the period of office of this Labor Government. Those figures speak for themselves. The situation is getting progressively worse, and fewer and fewer people can afford housing.

I wish to address two broad areas. In regard to both of those areas I point out that there is absolutely no difference between the Government and the Opposition. I refer to the themes pursued by both major parties of growth for growth's sake-undifferentiated growth, growth without thought to the consequences of growth-and the processes of deregulation. Dealing first with the problem of population growth, in the September 1988 quarter our migration program added more people to Australia's population than the natural rate of population increase. Fifty-seven per cent of the population increase in that quarter was due to the migration program. Of the 66,000 people who were added to the population at that time, 37,700 were migrants. I do not in any sense blame migrants; I blame the policy of the Government, which seeks to pack more people into Australia without thought to where those people will live and their impact on the urban centres of Australia.

Migrants generate added pressure for housing. It is quite clear that most of the children born during the September quarter will live with their parents, whereas most of those 37,700 migrants will be adults. They require not only houses but also schools, recreation facilities, sewage disposal facilities, roads, water catchment areas, garbage disposal, et cetera. The pursuit of population increase for its own sake-nobody has established that migration is of any net economic benefit to this country-is one of the major factors adding to the strain on housing. I point out yet again that the Opposition would pursue policies of population growth greater than those of the Government. It is committed to a greater migration program than that of the Government.

Senator Cook said that we are in need of skills. One of the claims for the migration program is that we need to bring in people with skills. We have had a migration program since 1947. If we still do not have enough skilled people here to build houses, it reflects very badly on our educational system and our ability to train young people in the housing area. It is about time we did something about that rather than simply trying to pack more people into the country. Eighty per cent of population increase since 1947 has accrued in urban areas. That situation continues today. That applies both to the natural increase and to the increase due to migration. That is the primary source of pressure on the urban areas and the demand for housing. If one takes the market view of the economy, which both the Government and the Opposition do, then prices go up when there is a demand for a limited supply. When one adds to that the deregulatory programs which have been pursued by the Government the situation is exacerbated.

In recent days the Treasurer, Mr Keating, has said that the answer to this problem is to pack more people into our cities; we need higher density housing. What right does Mr Keating or anybody else have to dictate to Australians the way in which they will live when they have made it quite clear that they would prefer to live in more open cities? In most cases, they would prefer a quarter acre block. It has been identified that there are enormous advantages in terms of safe areas for children to play in, the ability to grow vegetables in the back garden, exercise, isolation from neighbours, less noise pollution and so on. It has been identified that people want to live on quarter acre blocks. That is not to say that we should not be building more high density housing for some people, but it should not be forced on an unwilling population because we have a population explosion. The figures show quite clearly that the majority of Australians are not in favour of the high migration rates which are being pursued by this Government and the high migration rates which would be pursued by the Opposition.

There is substantial decay in our urban infrastructure as a consequence of population increase. The figures which were given by the South Australian Government to the FitzGerald Committee to advise on Australia's Immigration Policies indicate that the South Australian Government will need to spend $800m over the next five years on urban infrastructure. But in the next five-year period the Government will need to spend $3 billion on the maintenance of urban infrastructure, which will totally soak up all the public funding in that area leaving no money whatsoever to provide new infrastructure for the new population. In just the last couple of weeks we have seen three major water mains burst in Adelaide which have obstructed roads and traffic for days at a time. Infrastructure in Adelaide is simply wearing out. The pressure for population increase can only reduce the quality of life for people living in our major cities.

In the press in recent days there has been a call for South Australia and Western Australia to bring water in from the Ord River-build a pipeline right across Australia at a cost of $8 billion. That water would cost every single family about $3,500 per year simply to pay the capital cost on the pipeline, the amortisation of that capital cost and the interest payments without ever pumping one single drop of water through that pipeline. That is the end product of this blind pursuit of growth for growth's sake which is the policy of both the Government and the Opposition. The growth model, as I have indicated on several previous occasions, has a large number of faults.

It is perhaps appropriate at this point to interpolate that Senator Walsh has admitted that many of the things which are costs are put down as benefits. When I asked a question relating to motor vehicle accidents and where those costs appeared, pointing out that they appeared on the positive side of the national accounts as an addition to gross national product, and that the money we would spend on a pipeline across Australia to pump water would not appear as a cost but would appear as an addition to gross domestic product, Senator Walsh pointed out that if we were to exclude some of these costs it would `require more fundamental changes to the accounts-indeed, to the extent where it could touch off a spiral in which all the gross domestic product gradually disappeared'. Senator Walsh recognises that, if we did our national accounting correctly, the apparent conflict between the perception which ordinary people have-that they are becoming worse off-and the claim by the Treasurer and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) that, because the gross national product is increasing, we are becoming better off would be adequately explained.

The second major policy direction being followed by the Government and supported by the Opposition is the policy of deregulation. There is, of course, a fundamental flaw in the market system on which this philosophy is based. It is based ultimately on the idea of Adam Smith that there is an invisible hand which will mean that the operation of unfettered competitive greed will somehow serve the common good. That is absolute nonsense. It has been nonsense since the days of Adam Smith, and it is surprising to me that economists and politicians in this place can still mouth such absolute stupidities. There is absolutely no a priori reason why the operation of competitive greed should serve the common good. One can build mathematical models which show that the so-called level playing field-a term much used in this place-the sine qua non of the market system that everybody is equal within the market and all competing together, is the most unstable position in a market system. It will hunt very rapidly towards monopoly positions. What we find in practice is that it hunts very rapidly towards monopoly positions. The players who get a slight advantage on that level playing field very quickly determine that that is the way it will go.

We have deregulated the interest rate system, and we have allowed foreign speculators to come in and speculate against our currency. I do not know what the figure is now, but several years ago it was suggested that $50 trillion was sloshing around in the international money markets, speculating substantially against the Australian dollar. This has meant that financial institutions have been able to get an advantage over ordinary home buyers. We find that there is no shortage of building activity. But where is the building activity going on? It is going on in our major cities. Every skyline in Australia is festooned with giant cranes building office space while people are desperately short of housing. We have a 17 per cent vacancy rate in office space at present. The Government has allowed speculators to go into the market. Thirty per cent of dwelling transactions in Australia now are going to investors. Investors are heavily involved and they are speculating against those who desperately need housing.

This Government has introduced negative gearing, and it has allowed speculators in that system to speculate even more unfairly against genuine home buyers. For instance, if the interest rate is 16 per cent, a person who pays 50 per cent tax is effectively paying 8 per cent interest rate on his home loan, whereas the person who buys a house to live in is paying the full 16 per cent. Moreover, the speculator, if he or she makes a loss, simply writes the loss off against that tax. The well-off are being given an advantage over the poor. Shame on this Labor Government for allowing that to happen.

We have allowed foreign ownership to be completely unregulated. I notice that even the Australian Council of Trade Unions is calling for action to close foreign investment loopholes and to stop foreign investment and foreign speculation in Australian real estate.
