SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), who led the debate for the Government in response to this urgency motion, that the crisis in housing is a matter of urgency. He tried to pretend that our bringing the matter forward was a stunt and that it ought not be a matter for discussion while the housing summit is taking place. He used a range of words to describe our interest in this crisis-petty, tawdry, carping and transparent. He obviously lacked anything of substance to say if he had to resort to accusing us of raising the matter at the time of the mighty summit. We have had summits before. We are used to finding out exactly how little we get out of them. We have had a tax summit, an economic summit and a drug summit, all of which have been great talkfests. Such summits provide a great opportunity for people to say a great deal, but not much comes out of them. Senator Cook confirmed that when he indicated that today's housing summit was focusing on the supply of land. He said that that supply was a matter that was being addressed. Of course land is important, but he made no mention whatever of the cost of servicing land and making it available to people, not to mention the cost of buying houses to put on the land to those who might want to provide their families with homes. The Minister made no mention of the burden of interest payments that such people would have to pay if they were to provide a home in that way. Talk about the supply of land is merely the tip of the iceberg. Why does the Government not get around to talking about its economic policies, which have driven interest rates to their present level? High interest rates mean that many people are not able to maintain the payments on their homes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister indicated that the burden of Labor policy, to use his words, was to enable Australians to move into home ownership. He then went on to talk about the first home owners scheme and to boast about the amount of money that Labor has put into it. He spoke of the number of households to have benefited from it, and referred to it as being outstandingly successful. It is a pity that he has fled from the chamber and is not here to answer my question. If Labor is doing so much, how is it that the first home owners scheme now provides only 5 per cent of the cost of buying a first home, although when it first started it provided approximately 11 per cent of the cost. Honourable senators who consider that fact in conjunction with the interest rates that have to be paid on the mortgage will get some appreciation of how little benefit the first home owners scheme confers under Labor.

It is interesting to reflect a little on the housing situation. In 1942, when Robert Menzies gave the speech that has now been referred to as his `forgotten people' speech-even that phrase is worth remembering at a time like this-he said:

The material home represents the concrete expression of the habits of frugality and saving for a home of your own. Your advanced socialist may rage against private property . . . but one of the best instincts in us is that which induces us to have one little piece of earth with a house and a garden which is ours: to which we can withdraw, in which we can be among friends, into which no stranger may come against our will.

It is the belief of the Liberal Party that people still want their own homes. It is very interesting to consider the way in which the Minister dealt with the topic; I will return to that a little later.

I refer specifically to the realities of the Australian Capital Territory, the area that I represent. In June of 1988, not so long ago, the average loan on a house was $60,386. The repayment on such a loan over 25 years at the then interest rate of 13.5 per cent was $704 a month-quite a lot of money out of one's wage. Total payments on that $60,000 loan amounted to $150,772. In just six months-to December 1988-with the same average loan of just over $60,000, with the interest rate that had gone up in six months to 15 per cent, the monthly repayments had gone up to $773, bringing a total for that house of $171,653 or an additional $20,881. There are few in this community who have been able to find easily the extra money to pay that increased monthly repayment of an additional $70.

A number of ways have been found to try to meet this problem-extending the loans, rewriting the loans, maintaining the payment at the original figure and just writing the rest of it on to the loan-but few people have any real appreciation of the actual consequence to their property of doing that. The amount that one owes escalates, not just at the amount of $70-odd a month, if, in fact, one has elected to pay the original rate and not the new rate. Within a very short time one can finish up owing more on one's mortgage than the house is worth. There have been houses sold in Canberra where that has been the case. Normally if one sells a house one hopes to go to another one. There are many people who have had to sell, who find they are in debt and then are left at the mercy of trying to find accommodation when their credit rating is at its lowest, when they have no prospects of finding a deposit for a new house-even that meagre 5 per cent to which I referred earlier-and when they are not a first home loan purchaser.

We have been referring so far to those who have a home. What about those who are just starting out? It is worth spending a minute or two looking at the plight that they are in. Again, as recently as 9 February the Canberra Times reported that in relation to homes the Australian Capital Territory's figures were the worst. The paper reported in some detail the research of the Commonwealth Bank and the Housing Industry Association. I shall refer briefly to it. It said:
The outlook for new home buyers worsened considerably throughout Australia in the three months to December-
that is, of 1988-
with the situation deteriorating most in Canberra, according to a survey by the Housing Industry Association and the Commonwealth Bank.
The worsening of the already gloomy outlook for would-be home buyers occurred as housing prices and interest rates rose.
I interpose to remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that interest rates have risen even further since then. It goes on:
Canberra experienced the biggest rise in the price of established houses in any capital city during the last quarter of 1988, with prices jumping 15 per cent.
And reflecting the way new home buyers have been priced out of the market, the price of newly built houses-those which are bought predominantly by new home buyers-slumped in Canberra.

It goes on to talk about the prices of houses in the median and lower end of the market and points out that it is not that people do not need homes, but that they just cannot afford to purchase them. That is one aspect of it but few would have failed to have been moved by the article in the Sydney Morning Herald in November last which was headed `The new price of a home-no kids for 10 years'. That is the gloomy prospect that many young people embarking on marriage face at this time. It said:
Many young couples are agreeing to put off having children for up to 10 to 15 years to qualify for a home loan in Sydney.
That applies to Sydney but similar sorts of stories relate to other markets around the country. It goes on:
More than two-thirds of borrowers were relying on both incomes to repay their loan.
It goes on to refer to other aspects of the matter including the rise in the median price of houses. It continues:

The coordinator of Credit Line, Mrs Betty Weul, said many couples were committed to such a heavy outlay that they had to cut expenses for food ``down to rock bottom'', had no money for entertainment and could not afford a family for up to 15 years.

Can honourable senators imagine the stress and strain that that places on a relationship, the stress placed on a family which cannot afford to continue to retain the house in which it lives, the stress which is placed on a marriage where the couple know they cannot embark on having a family for 10 to 15 years? It would be bad enough if we were merely talking about the increased cost of housing, but in fact that is not all families have had to face.

In Canberra, for example, one would be foolish indeed not to have private health insurance if one wanted to protect one's family adequately. Since 1983, under the Labor Government, the state of the hospital system is such that one cannot rely on getting health care in Canberra when it is needed. Certainly, in the case of a major accident, one would be admitted to a hospital. But how many people have had to go to Sydney for treatment, causing great disruption to their families? How many have had to go to Wagga to have bones set? How many aged are living in very difficult circumstances because of the shortage of nursing home beds in Canberra? I could go on and on for the rest of the afternoon recounting the health services plight in Canberra.

There are other ways in which families have suffered as a consequence of Labor policies apart from having to pay for private health cover. To return to that, the Minister for Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Reynolds), when answering a question today, referred to the advantages families have had from Medicare. She should hang around Canberra a bit longer and find out exactly what families do not get under Medicare. She also claimed that Medicare had saved families $21 a week. If one just relies on Medicare, that is fine if one is fit and healthy and does not need health care. But what about the extra cost of having to pay a Medicare levy and having to provide private health cover so that a family can be sure to get the assistance it needs when needed?

There is a whole range of other taxes which have been referred to already in this debate. One might say that these taxes relate to other people and not to families, especially low income families. But the cost of sales tax, fringe benefits tax and superannuation taxes flows into the community and is finally paid for by consumers. To pretend that that is not the case is to fly in the face of the reality of the situation. This is the highest taxing government in peacetime. That fact is also reflected in the report which, interestingly enough, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women had not read this morning. The report, prepared by the Institute of Family Studies, is titled Families and Tax in 1989. Time does not permit me this afternoon to refer to the references it makes to all the ways in which families have been disadvantaged, particularly in the area of tax. It mentions that tax has gone up by 107 per cent for most taxpayers-not high income earners, but most taxpayers, and that is the reality.

At last Senator Cook got down to the thing he was really boasting about-the difference between Labor and Liberal. He referred to public housing and what is being spent in that area. I am glad he did, because it is not our business to keep people in rented accommodation. Our aim is to enable people to purchase their own homes. He did not refer to the 60,000 homeless: he did not refer to the 40,000 people who sleep in refuges or in the open at night. He talked about the number of people who had been put into rental accommodation by this Government. I talk about the number of people who aim for their own accommodation. He did not talk about the fact that whereas, in 1982, to our shame, there were 110,000 people on public housing waiting lists, now, some seven years later, under Labor there are 160,000 people on public housing waiting lists. He avoided that issue. He did not refer to the study of Pugh and Catt, conducted in South Australia in 1984, which said that every $1m spent by government would provide 162 public houses. But if the same money is spent on private ownership, 280 people would be assisted. These are the realities.

In 1982-83, 56 per cent of the housing budget went to public housing; last year it was 77 per cent. The Government has got it all wrong in every respect. It is incapable of keeping inflation under control. It is incapable of arresting interest rates. I wonder whether it is capable of delivering tax relief. We are entitled to doubt it because the Government is certainly not able to provide an environment where young Australians are able to get their own homes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason why the coalition's solutions to the housing problem, which we acknowledge, are poles apart from the Government's solutions is really in the concepts it has of the housing problem. Its concepts are fundamentally different from those of the Government and so its solutions are consequently different.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, members of the Opposition are focusing on the symptoms of the current housing problem, not the causes. For example, they see high cost housing as related uniquely to interest rates and, as a result, suggest a relaxation of interest rates. Apart from the broader economic effects of such a decision in an overheated economy, the effect would simply be to increase price pressures further. The simple fact is that if we want to see the cost of housing drop we have to attack it from the supply side. We cannot attack it from the demand side unless either the level of household disposable income drops-does the Opposition really want a recession?-or the expectations of the community are reduced and this is something over which governments have little direct control in the short term.

The broader economic implications cannot be ignored. The Commonwealth Government has a limited range of options in dealing with economic problems. Its main tools are fiscal policy, wages policy and monetary policy. If pressure is taken off interest rates, which effectively excludes the monetary policy option, it puts greater emphasis on the other two-fiscal and wages policies. I would like somebody on the Opposition benches to tell me how a greater emphasis on wages policy, which means a reduction in wages, not an increase in wages, or fiscal policy restraint, which means reductions in expenditure, can help the housing affordability problem for the average Australian. I do not see too many willing to answer that.

The second significant difference is in the Opposition's narrow concept of housing. I notice that this is shared by the Australian Democrats as well, if Senator Coulter is a true spokesman for them. I might say that I am surprised at his views. A reading of the Liberal Party's waffly and superficial document, Future Directions, which I think might be more aptly described as `Looking Backwards to the Future', leaves two impressions. The first is one of vagueness and lack of direction. It is so generalised as to be almost meaningless. But in so far as it does come to grips with specifics in relation to the housing industry, its narrow concept of housing involving home ownership in a stereotyped traditional form is, I suppose, what leads to the policy pronouncements that are being alluded to today. There is no recognition in that document, there is no recognition in the many statements that have been made to the media since that document was produced, of the growing complexities of housing needs in an increasingly diverse and complex society. Some of those matters have already been alluded to by Senator Cook.

The Opposition policy revolves around two half-baked ideas: firstly, the concept of mortgage insurance cover for 100 per cent mortgages, and, secondly, repayment assistance, but with no indication at all of how much that would be. Let us look first at mortgage insurance cover for 100 per cent mortgages. Assuming that press reports are correct-and we have a difficulty here because the document tells us nothing and the press releases dribble out giving us little bits of information, but it is very hard to get to grips with what the Liberal Party's policy really is-and this cover is limited to people on $15,000 incomes or less, the obvious conclusion must be that for these people repayments must be unacceptably high as a percentage of income, or that the government repayments subsidy must be very large indeed.

Let us look more closely at the 100 per cent mortgage insurance concept. While no deposit 100 per cent mortgages assist home buyers to bridge the deposit gap, repayments on a typical house would represent a prohibitively high proportion of low income earners' incomes. For example, a 100 per cent conventional mortgage on a $80,000 house would require monthly repayments of $1,083. Low income borrowers with no deposit-that is, with 100 per cent mortgages-could be forced to pay well above 25 to 30 per cent of their income in repayments. To give a very specific example, for a first home buyer in Sydney buying a medium priced house for $117,000 on no deposit at 15.5 per cent interest over 30 years, the monthly repayments would be about $1,526 or about 70 per cent of average weekly earnings before tax.

That is far too high to be contemplated in any realistic government policy and makes nonsense of the Opposition's policy pronouncements on housing, which are fairly vague at this stage. Mortgage insurance might be very useful to the lender but is not of much use to the borrower faced with these sorts of repayments. The Government recognises that there is a problem, but sees the nature of the problem differently from the Opposition. Firstly, it recognises that this is a supply side problem, and it must be dealt with in economic terms that address that reality. Secondly, it recognises the complexity of the housing question in what is, as I have said, a rapidly changing society with different values from the stereotypical values that are presented in the document that I referred to before, Future Directions.

Its response is measured and appropriate, and contains essentially two elements. The first is that land is to be released. This was announced before the Premiers Conference as an offer of goodwill to show that the Commonwealth Government is not simply going to sit back and avoid any responsibility. I must say that I am a little amused at some of the implications of what the Opposition has been saying, because it seems to propose giving the Commonwealth Government an awful lot more power in this question of housing than its States rights attitude would normally allow it to support and which it demonstrated in referendums such as those we have just had.

Housing is essentially a State problem. We recognise that. We recognise that we are limited in what we can do about it. Other than just adjusting the broad economy or doing such things as releasing land, we can do what the Commonwealth Government often does, and that is to assist State governments by means of exhortation, by means of drawing them in and trying to develop, in consultation some sorts of creative solutions to what are pressing and difficult problems.

As I have said, the Government's response is, I believe, a measured and appropriate one, comprising two elements. The first is the releasing of land. It needs to be said that this is no mean offer to the States. The land that we are talking about releasing is equivalent to 15 new suburbs and will go a long way towards overcoming one of the problems on the supply side, and that is the shortage of land. The second, of course, is encouraging by means of the Premiers Conference and by other means at the Government's disposal creative ways of providing the changes that are needed in the approaches that governments are taking to housing, recognising that we are a rapidly changing society.

For example, we need to recognise that demands are no longer uniform or stereotyped. They are very varied, in fact. The quarter-acre block is by no means a universal desire. It might be widespread, but attitudes are rapidly changing. Many people I know would far prefer to live close to the city in smaller apartment units where they have manageable gardens and are able to use public transport. This is a growing trend in the larger cities but even in my city of Perth there is a great pressure on governments, particularly at the State and local level, for that sort of housing. Unfortunately, in a lot of the things that local governments are doing I do not see any attempts being made to meet those sorts of changing and specialised demands. Paddy McGuinness in this morning's Australian drew attention to the fact that the biggest failure in the area of creative solutions to the housing problem is at a local government level-not at a Federal or State government level. That is where the creativity is needed. So it may ultimately be that, as part of this debate that we are having across the nation on housing, we need to draw in local government and try to get it exposed to some of the ideas that we are talking about here and the ideas that I hope the Premiers Conference will address.

We need to recognise also that we are an ageing society with a growing number of single parent families and families of a smaller size than they formerly were. So changes are occurring there. The housing needs of those various groups are quite different from the housing needs of the stereotypical family in Future Directions outside the front of their quaint and outmoded mansion with their FJ Holden beside it. It is all idealised and nice, and I can understand how the Liberal Party hopes that it will have the public relations effect of making people feel soft and mushy about its policies. But I think people are a little wiser and they will want to see some substance there before they are prepared to change their vote.

We need also to recognise that as a result of all these things, our lifestyles and housing needs are changing rapidly. Unlike the Opposition, I welcome the Premiers Conference to discuss the housing question. I do not shy away from the fact that we have a problem, but I do not believe that we will solve that problem by the sorts of nonsensical solutions or the vague generalisations that I have heard from the Opposition benches. I think we will solve these problems by hard-headed, economic, rational decisions, on the one hand, and some divergent creative thinking, on the other hand, to try to meet the changing demands of a very rapidly changing society which the Opposition just does not seem to want to face. As I have said, I welcome the Premiers Conference to discuss the housing question. I trust that it will put aside political point-scoring and make a genuine attempt to meet some of those creative needs that I have talked about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the urgency motion which is in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to change its policies which are depriving increasing numbers of young Australians of the opportunity to own their own homes.

That is a self-evident truth. Nothing that Government speakers have said so far denies the fact that an increasing number of young Australians are being deprived of the opportunity to own their own homes. That point has been conceded effectively by every Government speaker. The only point on which they are in disagreement with us is the manner of resolving that problem. The last speaker, Senator Beahan, admitted that we have a problem. It is a massive, mounting problem that strikes at the very heart of one of the major beliefs that all Australians have-that is, that they are entitled to own their own homes. It is an entitlement that this Government is destroying by a deliberate set of massively high interest rate policies which it is using to try to resolve the economic problems it has created for this country. The Government's policy of high interest rates is a deliberate economic policy and that policy is playing a major role in pricing Australians out of the housing market and forcing Australians out of their homes.

The interesting thing that the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, said was that this motion-which on the Government's own admission and, in effect, from its own speakers, is basically right; young Australians are being deprived of the opportunity of owning their own homes-was simply a political stunt. Of course, the reality is that the only political stunt on today is the so-called housing summit. It is a stunt that has been put on after the latest inflation figures showed that Mr Keating was wrong again. We have continually seen Mr Keating being wrong in all his Budget forecasts ever since he lost his previous economic adviser, Professor Barry Hughes, who had the good sense at Budget time to say that the Treasurer was going to be wrong on all these matters. Of course, Professor Hughes was exactly right, along with the Opposition, which also indicated that all those forecasts were absolute nonsense.

The simple reality is that the recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying a home beyond the reach of most Australian families. Since last June savings bank home mortgage interest rates have risen from 13.5 per cent to a record 15.5 per cent and are expected to go even higher. While the phoney housing summit called by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) today in Canberra avoids dealing with the real housing crisis, there has been a genuine discussion of the real issues going on in Sydney. It was a protest rally in Martin Place, appropriately enough outside the Reserve Bank of Australia. That meeting did deal with the major issue which speakers here from the Government have ducked and avoided and which the Prime Minister is ducking and avoiding at the so-called housing summit, and that issue is the Government's huge and deliberate policy of massive interest rates.

I can assure Senator Cook that that rally will receive far more publicity in Sydney, where people recognise the threat to their homes of this massive high interest rate policy, than Senator Cook's pathetic contribution to this debate. The rally reflects the growing across the board anger at the way interest rates are killing off home ownership hopes of so many Australians, apart from lowering everyone's general standard of living. That rally, organised by the Australian Small Business Association and held in Sydney at lunchtime, is the first stage of a major campaign against high interest rates involving, ASBA says, a nationwide petition to the Federal Parliament so that the Australian people can give the Hawke Government a clear warning that excessive and damaging dependence on a high interest rate policy will not be tolerated, especially in an election year.

Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times. Many of them will never pay off their mortgage and will go further and further into debt under these high interest rates unless the Hawke Government stops this damaging and offensive policy. But the trouble is that the Hawke Government's present policy is to keep interest rates high and possibly push them even higher to try to fix up the mess it has made of the economy.

Today's housing summit in Canberra is a farce. It is not aimed at solving the real home ownership disaster of record interest rates. The Hawke Government simply does not want more Australians buying their own homes. I stress that: it is not the Hawke Government's policy at the moment to want Australians to buy their own homes. That aspiration to buy one's own home is totally in conflict with the economic policies of the Hawke Government at the moment. Mr Ross Gittins explained in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday that increased home ownership conflicts with the economic policies of trying to dampen things down. So the Hawke Government will continue to do what it can, through record interest rates, to dampen down demand for housing. `Dampen down' means in effect to pour cold water on the hopes of Australian families of owning their own homes. That is what dampening down means-pouring cold water on the proper aspirations of all Australians, particularly those young Australians seeking to have a home of their own for their families.

The Hawke Government has deliberately chosen high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon to deal with our balance of payments and inflation crises. Mr Hawke himself has warned that interest rates will stay high-of course they could even go higher-until the economic crisis is resolved. Six weeks ago Mr Hawke said, `I don't think there's any purpose in holding a national housing summit', even though official and private surveys showed the extent of the housing crisis. But two weeks later he called the summit simply as a political stunt to shift the blame for the latest disastrous inflation figures onto Sydney's high house prices instead of his Government's failed economic policies. The most important causes of the housing crisis-particularly huge interest rates-are not even on the agenda for today's housing summit that Government speakers have pretended is addressing the main issue.

Who are the people being hurt by huge interest rates? It goes across the whole spectrum. It involves not just the home seekers, people who want to buy a home and are confronted with 15.5 per cent interest rates for building society and savings bank loans; people with existing mortgages who bought their home particularly in the last 12 months when interest rates were down to 13.5 per cent are suddenly finding that they face a far bigger mortgage interest bill than they believed they would.

Let us look at home seekers, who are being priced out of the market. They would face monthly mortgage repayments far beyond their earning capacity simply to buy an average home. For example, the repayment would be $1,320 a month-that is, $308 a week-on a 15.5 per cent, 25-year savings bank mortgage of $100,000, which by the way is about $154 a month more than it would have been last June. The only families who can afford that, according to affordability surveys based on 25 per cent of family income, would be those Australians earning more than $63,000 a year. That is way above the average Australian family's income. Yet an average Sydney home now costs $160,000. Therefore, the average Sydney new home buyer would need a mortgage of at least $100,000. The fact is that unless one is earning $63,000 a year one cannot afford to get a mortgage to buy an average Sydney home.

Recent home buyers with mortgages also face this terrible problem because their mortgages were taken out at lower interest rates and they now face either huge increases in monthly repayments or the extension of their loans. They will never own their own home. For example, the interest-only cost of $100,000 mortgage at 13.5 per cent taken out last June is about $1,125 a month, which is well covered by the monthly repayments of $1,166. But at 15.5 per cent-the new Hawke rate-the interest-only cost rises to almost $1,300 a month, or almost $130 a month more than the monthly repayment rate if it were maintained and the length of the loan extended. This means that after a year of repayments in which the home owner has paid $14,000 in mortgage costs, he would end up a further $1,500 in debt and would never own his own home-that is, unless interest rates fell or he eventually faced up to huge rises in his monthly repayments.

Most home owners with mortgages have been temporarily protected from the full impact of the Government's high interest rate policies by banks and building societies, which hope that the problem will go away sooner or later. But borrowers will have to pay the full bill sooner or later. Relatively few home owners with mortgages have been hit with increased monthly mortgage repayments that fully reflect the Hawke Government's huge interest rate rises. Instead, the banks and building societies have hidden the impact of higher interest rates by extending the length of the loan. In other words, the Government should be very grateful to the banks and building societies for protecting so many Australians from the harsh and immediate reality of these hugh interest rate rises. But they cannot do that forever.

Meanwhile Australian home owners are going further and further into debt. Lenders are not increasing monthly repayments because thousands of Australians would be forced out of their homes if repayments matched the interest rate rises. The banks and building societies unfairly cop much of the flak from this, instead of the people who are directly responsible-this Hawke Government. The Hawke Government is entirely to blame for this disaster. It is a disaster not only in economic terms but also in social terms. The Marriage Guidance Council, for example, has made the point very strongly that the number of people seeking guidance due to the housing crisis is putting a strain on the Council's resources. Soaring house prices and interest rates have taken a heavy toll on marriages.

The crisis facing housing has been caused largely by this Government. Certainly the interest rate crisis has been entirely created by this Government. This Government must cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead must use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market and many Australians out of their homes, so that the traditional right of ownership is returned to average Australian families. I have great pleasure in supporting the urgency motion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 1 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are 100,000 dolphins deliberately killed in the eastern tropical Pacific each year, as a result of purse seine fishing for yellowfin tuna which swim beneath and behind dolphin herds.

(2) Has the Federal Government expressed its opposition to the slaughter of dolphins to the responsible governments, namely Mexico, the United States, Venezuela, Ecuador, Vanuatu, Spain, Cayman Islands, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Panama and the Soviet Union.

(3) Will the Government ban the import of yellowfin tuna caught in the eastern tropical Pacific until the killing of dolphins ends, and the level of incidental dolphin deaths is reduced to negligible levels.
(4) What other actions has the Government taken, or will it take, to help end this deliberate killing of dolphins, and to ensure that Australia is not involved in it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Question No. 575 has already been answered, in general terms, by a response to a question without notice asked by Senator Sanders on 30 September 1988 (see Senate Hansard dated 30 September 1988, pp. 1135-36). A more detailed response to Question No. 575 is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The fishing methods employed in the Eastern Tropical Pacific (ETP) tuna fishery are the most serious cause of marine mammal mortality in the world. Since the inception of the fishery in 1959, it has been estimated that more than 6 million dolphins have been killed as a result of purse seine fishing for yellowfin tuna which swim beneath and behind schools of dolphins. Incidental deaths of dolphins for the years to 1983 to 1987 reportedly have been 24,000, 29,400, 56,700, 129,500 and 115,000 respectively.

(2) The Federal Government has, through its diplomatic missions abroad, expressed its concern to all Governments whose fishing fleets are involved in the incidental dolphin kill. This concern was also raised at a meeting between the then Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, and the Foreign Minister of Mexico, Mr Sepulveda, held in Canberra, on 27 July 1988.

(3) The Federal Government believes that the incidental dolphin kill would not cease or be reduced simply by banning the import of yellowfin tuna caught in the ETP. The most likely outcome of any such ban would, in fact, be economic hardship for blameless parties, particularly the less developed countries in which most of the world's tuna is processed. Moreover, it is almost impossible to determine whether or not tuna processed outside Australia has come from the ETP tuna fishery due to the industry practice of mixing together the tuna caught from various tuna fisheries throughout the world.

(4) The Federal Government has, in addition to the representations referred to above, expressed in general terms at the 40th meeting of the International Whaling Commission (IWC) (Auckland 30 May-3 June 1988) its concern at the incidental dolphin kill. The Federal Government will continue to use diplomatic channels in its attempt to bring about a cessation or reduction of the incidental dolphin kill.

The concern of the Federal Government reflects its policy of seeking protection for all cetaceans (dolphins, porpoises and whales) worldwide. It is not possible for Australia to directly enforce this policy in external waters such as the ETP. In Australian waters, however, cetaceans are protected by the Whale Protection Act 1980 which prohibits the killing, taking, injuring or interference with any cetacean (including dolphins). The Act recognises, however, that in licensed commercial fishing operations cetaceans may be unintentionally killed or captured. The Act specifies that in these circumstances, captured cetaceans must be released immediately and that any incident of a cetecean being taken, killed or injured must be reported to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories as soon as practicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 1 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How much Australian aid is presently going to Fiji and what is the nature of that aid.

(2) Has there been a change in the amount and nature of Australian aid to Fiji since the recent military coups in that country; if so, to what extent has that change resulted from Australian Government reservations about the political situation in Fiji.
(3) Has the Minister considered withdrawing aid assistance to Fiji while the government of that country continues to maintain and use the military as an internal police force.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia's aid program to Fiji for 1988/89 is budgeted at $22 million. This is made up of two components; the regular aid program of $12 million and an additional ``one off'' $10 million special assistance program. The regular program is being implemented in accordance with priorities set by the Government of Fiji and the Australian Government and concentrates on projects of benefit to the entire Fiji community including the development of public utilities, agriculture, training and staffing assistance and small grants for village level development.

A phased implementation of the special assistance program was announced on 22 November 1988 with initial expenditure of $4.84 million. The package is directed specifically at the most obvious and urgent humanitarian needs of the community in Fiji and has a particular emphasis on health, education and welfare. The special assistance program will be reviewed again in early 1989 to consider whether implementation of the $5.16 million balance of the program is feasible and warranted.

(2) There has been a change in the amount and nature of Australian aid to Fiji since the military coups in 1987. In summary Australia's aid to Fiji for F/Y 1986/87 was programmed at a level of $14 million and concentrated on the agriculture, fisheries, engineering and welfare sectors. As a result of the freeze put on new aid activities following the first coup actual expenditure for 1986/87 totalled $11 million.

After the second coup in September 1987 all aid activities were terminated with the exception of sponsored students studying in Australia. Following the return to civilian government in Fiji certain activities which focused on support for disadvantaged groups, rural people, health services and training, were resumed, and expenditure for F/Y 1987/88 totalled $11,050,000. The answer to (1) sets out the current situation concerning the amount and nature of Australia's aid to Fiji.
The change in Australia's aid activities in Fiji since the coups reflects the Australian Government's concern that the aid program:
(a) benefits all the peoples of Fiji regardless of their ethnic origin.
(b) focuses on activities that are not directly or indirectly of a military nature nor provide support for military activities.

(3) The Australian Government deplored both Fiji coups and took action to suspend the provision of aid to Fiji (with the exception of training assistance). However on the return to civilian government in Fiji selected aid activities were resumed in early 1988, as outlined in (2).

The Australian Government has a firm and continuing commitment to a constructive relationship with Fiji and day to day dealings are an important aspect of continuing to rebuild the relationship. The reinstatement of the bilateral aid program is an important part of this on going process.

The interim Fiji Government has given firm assurances that equipment and materials supplied under the Australian program will not be diverted from intended purposes nor used to assist military activities in any way. The Australian Embassy in Suva monitors closely the implementation of Australian aid programs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 13 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of advice from the United Nations Information Office in Sydney that the organisation has no permanent contingency fund to grant immediate financial relief in the event of large-scale natural disasters, can Australia use its diplomatic and political influence within the United Nations to initiate a permanent contingency fund.
(2) Is it appropriate to suggest that member nations should contribute according to their means.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) In my view the concept of a permanent contingency fund for disaster relief under the auspices of the United Nations is not a practicable one.

In the event of large scale disasters donors, including Australia, would like to have the choice of whether to make a contribution, the amount and the form of that relief, and the channel through which it should be provided in order to gain recognition for the contribution and ensure that it is used effectively.
It is therefore unlikely that such a proposal would attract the necessary universal support from the international community.

The United Nations, in particular through the Office of the United Nations Disaster Relief Co-ordinator (UNDRO), does provide funding for an immediate, though limited, response to natural disasters. The information reports prepared and circulated by UNDRO during the initial emergency phase assist donors in determining the appropriate level of response required.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 13 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Noting a recent statement from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade that Australia should be spending at least 0.4 per cent of its Gross National Product on overseas aid, is this figure the minimum or maximum for the Federal Government in this area of spending.
(2) Has any timetable been set towards achieving the 0.4 per cent overseas aid goal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) In my address to the Ideas Centre in Sydney on 17 November 1988, I expressed a desire to see a significant movement in the ODA/GNP ratio towards 0.4 per cent within the next few bud- gets, a difficult achievement under the current tight budgetary constraints. I did not intend the 0.4 per cent figure to be interpreted in terms of either a minimum or maximum goal.

The Government adheres to a long term ODA/GNP target of 0.7 per cent set by the United Nations and will endeavour to maintain its ODA at the highest level consistent with the needs of developing countries and Australia's economic circumstances and capacity to assist.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 13 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With respect to the Parliamentary Brief of 24 November 1988, published by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid which is the co-ordinating body for about 80 organisations working in the field, has Australia fallen well behind comparable countries, such as Canada, France, the Netherlands and the Scandinavian nations, in its level of aid funding to less fortunate countries.
(2) Has Australia now been overtaken by Italy in donating aid, as expressed in terms of a percentage of Gross Domestic Product, and is Japan now the world's largest aid donor.
(3) Are figures available to the Australian Government on the aid levels provided by these countries in comparison with Australia; if so, what are they.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) According to the 1988 Annual Report by the Chairman of the Development Assistance Committee (DAC) of OECD, Australia's level of official development assistance (ODA) in calendar year 1987 was 0.33 per cent of GNP which was only slightly below the ratio of total ODA to total GNP for all DAC member countries (0.35 per cent in 1987).

However, some caution should be used in interpreting aid statistics published by the DAC. The DAC figures are compiled on a calendar year rather than financial year basis. The difficulty for Australia and other donors who report on a financial year basis is that the DAC figures are often distorted by the bunching of expenditure in one or another calendar year. The DAC figures do not reflect recent changes in Australian aid outlays announced in the 1988-89 budget. The 1988-89 budget provides for overseas aid outlays of $1,093.5m, an increase in real terms of 1.2 per cent on the previous financial year. Australia's overseas aid outlays for 1988-89 are expected to reach 0.36 per cent of GNP, slightly above the ratio of total DAC ODA to total DAC GNP.

Also there are two different methods of measuring official development assistance, either by an encashment or deposit basis. The difference relates to the method of recording certain contributions to international financial institutions. Some contributions are made in the form of promissory notes deposited in a bank and upon which the recipient institution can draw when it requires the funds.

The contribution may be counted as an aid flow at the time of the deposit of the promissory note in the bank (called the deposit method) or when the institution draws on the promissory note (known as the encashment method). Australia adopts the encashment approach for most reporting purposes whereas the DAC uses the deposit method for reporting international ODA statistics.

(2) According to the 1988 DAC Chairman's Annual Report, Italy's ODA/GNP ratio has fallen from 0.40 per cent in 1986 (lower than the Australian ODA/GNP ratio in 1986 of 0.47 per cent) to 0.35 per cent (slightly higher than the Australian ODA/GNP ratio in 1987.
In his 1988 Annual Report, the Chairman of the DAC stated that Japan was likely to become the largest DAC donor in either 1988 or 1989.
